Name:  ___                   Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___

Service: NEUROLOGY
 
Allergies: 
No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Headache
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Lumbar Puncture

 
History of Present Illness:
___ is a ___ year-old morbidly obese man with a long
list of chronic medical conditions (see below) who presents with
___ headache. The headache has been constant for nine days. It
has not responded to a long list of medications given at two
different outside hospitals for presumed migraine HA disorder.
The headache started rather suddenly nine days ago while he was
at an OSH for cardiac and GI workup for chest/epigastric pain.
This workup (at ___) was negative for PE with negative D-dimer,
negative for acute MI with negative troponins -- although
pulmonary hypertension and LVH were evident on echo -- and
positive for GERD / gastric erosions on EGD, treated 
successfully
by starting a PPI and metoclopromide. They were unable to
alleviate his headache despite attempted Tx with BDZ, narcotics,
aspirin, Fioricet, toradol, DHE, Zofran, and Imitrex. He was
discharged to home with a prescription for zolmitriptan 1.25mg
q2h PRN (in addition to the PPI and Reglan), which did not help,
and he returned to another OSH ED (___) for treatment of the
HA. They were unable to Dx or treat his HA effectively either. 
At
some point, an MRI was attempted in an outside facility with an
open/large-bore MRI, but his body habitus (almost 500 lbs)
prevented it.

His headache is throbbing and pounding in quality. The location
of the headache was initially in his mid-forehead, but soon 
after
extended back through primarily the left side of his head (it
does not extend as far as the right temple) and it extends back
to his neck. He says at times it feels like someone is pouding
his spine with a hammer. There is definite photophobia and mild
phonophobia and, interestingly, blurred vision which during the
examination below, the patient described as pulsatile. There has
been some nausea, no vomiting, but this does not seem to bother
him as much as the pain, photophobia, and blurred vision. There
is nothing that seems to make the HA go away, not even
temporarily. He is still able to sleep, and it does not seem to
awaken him from sleep, but it is present whenever he is awake. 
IV
opiate medication (Dilaudid 1mg) "takes the edge off" from ___
to ___ without actually diminishing the throbbing sensation,
photophobia, and pulsatile blurred vision. Besides the visual
symptoms listed above, he does not endorse any associated
Neurologic deficits or changes (see ROS below).

He said that before this 9-day headache, he can only recall one
or two headaches over the past ___ years, and neither was
anything near as severe as this. The only prolonged or severe
headache he had was around the age of ___, lasted several days,
didn't respond to OTC analgesics, and was a/w severe nausea and
several episodes of vomiting before it stopped. Thus, he does
have a history suspicious for migraine headache disorder, even 
if
it has not recurred in ___ years.

ROS:
On neuro ROS, the pt denies diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia,
lightheadedness, vertigo, tinnitus or hearing difficulty. Denies
difficulties producing or comprehending speech recently (says
generically he has experienced episodes of word-finding
difficulty in the past, but does not know the contex). Denies
focal weakness, numbness, parasthesiae. No bowel or bladder
incontinence or retention. Denies incoordination.

On general review of systems, the pt denies recent fever or
chills.  No night sweats or recent weight loss or gain. Denies
cough, shortness of breath.  Denies current chest pain or
tightness, palpitations.  Denies vomiting, diarrhea, 
constipation
or abdominal pain. No recent change in bowel or bladder habits. 
No dysuria. Denies arthralgias or myalgias. Denies rash.

at

**Visual fields are grossly restricted peripherally in all

**Fundoscopic examination was limited by patient eye movements /

elevation is symmetric. Eye closure is strong and symmetric.
Normal, symmetric facial elevation with smile.
VIII: Hearing is intact to finger-rub bilaterally. Pt. said

interference from loud BiPAP machine on the right.
IX, X: Palate elevates symmetrically.
XI: ___ equal strength in trapezii and SCM bilaterally.
XII: Tongue protrusion is midline.

-Motor:
No pronator drift, and no parietal up-drift bilaterally.
No tremor or fasciculations were observed. No asterixis.
Difficult to appreciate muscle bulk due to thick overlying fat.
Tone seemed normal. No flaccidity, hypertonicity, or spasticity
noted.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ was admitted to the neurology service on ___ 
with subacute headache which worsened over the course of 10 days 
to a severe pounding headache.  He had an LP which showed that 
he did not have a meningitis. Unfortunately, an opening pressure 
could not be obtained as an LP could not be done in the lateral 
decubitus position because of technical reasons, and could not 
be done in the interventional radiology fluoroscopy suite.  He 
had a CT head with vessel imaging (CTA/CTV) which did not show 
any abnormalities or evidence of  venous sinus thrombosis.  He 
was treated for presumed status migrainous with Medrol taper.  
He also received a Magnesium infusion. He initially improved, 
but then had more severe headache as well as visual symptoms.  A 
fundoscopic examination was limited as he could not tolerate it, 
however there was no optic disk abnormalities seen.  An LP was 
attempted on the floor but was unsuccessful.  For technical 
reasons related to his body weight and size, the LP could not be 
done in the interventional radiology suite with fluoroscopic 
guidance. Because we could not obtain an opening pressure and 
because symptoms did not completely improve and idiopathic 
intracranial hypertension could not be excluded, a decision was 
made to initiate empiric treatment with Acetazolamide for 
increased intracranial pressure (pseudotumor cerebri). 
Corresponding to this possibility was some blurring in the 
inferior nasal field of the left eye. His headache did improve 
after starting this.  He was also given muscle relaxants to 
treat a muscle spasm component to his pain, which was evident on 
palpation.

He was continued on all other home medications including his 
standing oxycontin and prn oxycodone for chronic backpain.  His 
Metformin was held as he received contrast, but was reinitiated 
upon discharge.  Blood sugars were monitored and he was 
maintained on a sliding insulin scale.  

We recommend limiting analgesics, avoiding nicotine, and formal 
visual field testing.  If headaches persist or worsen, chronic 
pain medications such as Amitriptyline or Topamax could be 
considered.

We would also recommend that weight loss measures, including 
possible bariatric surgery, be expedited to minimize the risk of 
permanent visual compromise.  A letter was given to Mr. ___ to 
this effect.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to ___ neurology service with severe 
headache for 9 days that did not respond to multiple 
medications.  You had a lumbar puncture in the emergency room 
and your spinal fluid was negative for meningitis. You had a 
head CT scan with vessel imaging which did not show any clots.  
You were started on high dose oral steroids to treat presumed 
"status migrainous" which is a persistent migraine headache.  
You were also given a magnesium infusion to help improve your 
headache. It also seems that you had a muscle spasm component to 
your pain, which can be relieved with hot packs. 

Because of your visual symptoms, and your risk of "pseudotumor 
cerebri," you were started Acetazolamide for presumed increased 
intracranial pressure.  

You will require labs prior to your appointment in the Neurology 
Clinic.  You will also need to see Ophthalmology for formal 
visual field testing. This has been arranged for you.  If you 
would like this to be done in ___, you can call your 
PCP to help you coordinate these tests.  

Weight loss will be a very important component to help improve 
your symptoms. We have provided you with a letter expressing our 
concerns about this diagnosis to help have your bariatric 
surgical evaluation expedited.

Brief Hospital Course:
This is the brief hospital course for a ___ year-old morbidly 
obese gentleman who presented with headache and syncope in the 
setting of chronic HTN, DMII, OSA, and a recent "possible," 
diagnosis of pseudotumor cerebri. The following is a problem 
list for the patient and the interventions which were done 
during this admission.
.
Syncope:
Normal EEG ruled out seizure. Cardiac etiologies were ruled out 
with normal telemetry, troponins, and numerous EKGs. His 
complaints of dizziness upon standing were suggestive of 
orthostatic hypotension as the cause of his syncope. 
Orthostatics normal during hospital stay, most likely dehydrated 
from acetazolamide use at home. 
-Encouraged PO intake on discharge
.
Headache: Neurology and ophthomology consults recommended 
full,complete ___ of pseudotumor cerebri. Due to patient's 
body habitus, LP for opening pressure and MRI for rule out 
lesion/infection could not be done here. Visual field testing 
should be performed as an outpatient.  
-Continue Acetazolamide 500 mg BID as outpatient.
-Follow-up with PCP in ___ for referral to neurologist 
and ophthomologist for visual field testing and management of 
pseudotumor cerebri as well as query into leukocytosis baseline.
.
Leukocytosis: No evidence of infection, afebrile entire hospital 
stay, no cough, negative UA. Patient with leukocytosis at 
baseline.
.
Chronic Low Back Pain: on narcotics for pain control: home 
Oxycotin and Oxycodone
.
OSA: BiPAP almost constantly while here, on it at home as well  
.  
Lower extremity edema: Non-pitting on lower extremities, on home 
lasix  
. 
HTN: Blood pressure under control, continue Metoprolol at home 
and lasix
. 
HL: Started Atorvastin 80 mg, continued Zetia
.  
Obesity: Morbid obesity, given fall precautions, nutrition 
consult 
. 
Asthma/COPD: Appears stable, continued home advair, albuterol  
.
DM2: Continue home Exenatide and Metformin
.
An appointment with the patient's PCP was scheduled for the 
following week. He was told and encouraged to attend to receive 
a neurologist and ophthomologist referral. The patient was also 
encouraged to remind his PCP to ___ his leukocytosis in 
further detail.

Brief Hospital Course:
He was admitted to ___ on ___ for cardiac 
catheterization. The study demonstrated moderate three vessel 
coronary coronary artery disease. He remained stable overnight 
and was taken to the operating room the next day. He underwent 
aortic valve replacement. Please see operative note for full 
details. He tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to 
the CVICU on neosynephrine and paced.  He was weaned from 
sedation that evening, awoke and was extubated.  POD 1 his chest 
tubes were removed, started Lasix, Lopressor and lisinopril.  
Later that evening he was weaned off nicardipine that had been 
started for blood pressure control.  However is blood glucose 
increased and he was restarted on insulin drip and remained in 
the CVICU.  He has baseline pseudodementia and that evening was 
mild confusion and agitation that he was given additional 
Seroquel above his home dose and was able to rest.  POD 2 his 
glipizide and insulin were further adjusted and he was weaned 
off the insulin drip.  Due to increased heart rate the 
lisinopril was stopped to allow further betablocker.  He 
continued to progress and was transferred to the floor and 
ramelteon was added for sleep.  POD 3 he was less interactive 
the ramelteon was discontinued and he was more interactive by 
the afternoon, Seroquel was reduced back to home dose of 12.5 mg 
BID, epicardial wires removed.  He was seen by physical therapy 
for strength and mobility, recommendation for home with ___, 
walker and family assistance.  His niece is very supportive and 
will be with him to assist at home. On post-operative day five 
he was discharged to his niece's home.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with history of severe 
idiopathic sensorimotor axonal polyneuropathy who comes in with 
worsening sympotms of parasthesias in upper and lower 
extremities bilaterally and worsening Rt. foot weakness. She has 
responded well to plasmapheresis in the past but has never 
completed the full 5 cycle series. She was admitted for elective 
plasmapheresis and close montioring as she has had concerning 
symptoms related to the treatment in the past. During her first 
pheresis she experienced abdominal pain, nausea, vomit x1, and 
lost control of her bowels x1. She also had low blood pressure, 
SBP of 100, during the high flow pheresis (70). She felt better 
on slow flow and had no sympotms after pheresis. The night 
before her second cycle of pheresis she was nauseous and vomited 
multiple times with abdominal pain. EKG was unchanged from prior 
ones. She tolerated her second pheresis well with minimal 
abdominal pain and felt relief from her N/V afterwards. The 
remaining cycles of pheresis went well.  Her neurologic exam 
showed improved strength and improved sensation.  She worked 
closely with physical therapy to get out of bed to chair.

During her hospitalization it was noted that she had elevated 
glucose levels.  We obtained a consult from the ___ Diabet___ 
___.  After further review of her labwork, it was concluded 
that she is indeed diabetic.  She received a nutrition consult 
for diabetic diet teaching.  Also, she was started on Metformin 
500 mg daily with dinner.  It was also noted that her she has 
low lipid levels so her simvastatin dose was decreased to 10 mg 
daily.  

On the ___, she was started on ciprofloxacin for a urine 
culture postive for gram negative rods >100,000.  Once 
sensitivities came back sensitive the same day, she was switched 
to nitrofurantoin with a plan for a 7 day course.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ woman with a severe, idiopathic large-fiber 
polyneuropathy or sensory neuronopathy, admitted for scheduled 
plasmapheresis in setting of continued progression of her 
numbness and proprioceptive sensory loss. 

# NEURO: Patient was admitted to the General Neurology service. 
Plasmapheresis line was placed without complication. She 
underwent 5 sessions of plasmapheresis. She was monitored on 
telemetry throughout given her history of coronary vasospasm 
with plasmapheresis. Her course was complicated by severe 
band-like lower abdominal pain following the first session, 
which was worked up extensively and found to be most likely 
related to transient vasospasm or fluid shifts after 
plasmapheresis, as well as an overly aggressive bowel regimen. 
Plasmapheresis was held for three days while her abdominal pain 
was treated. With vigorous hydration prior to plasmapheresis as 
well as supportive care with lorazepam for nausea, her abdominal 
pain was better controlled. She then underwent the next four 
sessions of plasmapheresis. On the evening following removal of 
her pheresis line, she spiked a fever to 102, likely related to 
transient bacteremia caused by line removal. Her line site 
appeared uninfected and infectious workup (blood cultures x2, 
urine culture, CXR) were normal. She remained afebrile for 24 
hours following this. 

On admission, patient's neuro exam was notable for atrophy in 
the small muscles of the hands and feet bilaterally, symmetric 
weakness of the extensors of the upper extremities, diffuse 
areflexia, decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick L>R, 
and severely decreased vibration and proprioception in the feet 
and lower legs bilaterally, and pseudoathetosis of both feet, 
all consistent with known diagnosis of severe sensorimotor 
polyneuropathy.  On discharge her neuro exam had improved 
slightly in that joint position sense at the ankles was mildly 
improved. Of note, it typically takes ___ weeks for patient to 
experience benefits from plasmapheresis. 

# ID: On admission, patient complained of dysuria and was found 
to have a UTI (E. coli, sensitive to everything but TMP-SMX). 
She was treated with a 5-day course of Ciprofloxacin and her 
symptoms improved.

___ multiple comorbidities presents with 8 hrs of mid/epigastric 
abdominal pain, nausea and nonbillous emesis, CT suggestive of 
partial small bowel obstruction. Her bowel obstruction is low 
grade on imaging and patient is not obstructed functionally. The 
patient is significantly symptomatic and is admitted to ___ 
service for serial abdominal exams with bowel rest and 
hydration. The patient was hemodynamically stable. 

On HD#2, the patient has a resolution of bowel obstruction, 
reporting large bowel movement and flatus. Diet was 
progressively advanced as tolerated to a regular diet with good 
tolerability. The patient voided without problem. During this 
hospitalization, the patient remained at her baseline activity 
of transferring to and from the bed independantly, was adherent 
with respiratory toilet and incentive spirometry, and actively 
participated in the plan of care. The patient received 
subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this 
stay.
.
At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, voiding without assistance, and pain was resolved.  The 
patient was discharged back to her assisted living residence. 
The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up 
instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with 
the discharge plan.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ yo F admitted to the Acute Care Surgery service 
with abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting. She has a past medical 
history significant for idiopathic axonal sensorimotor 
polyneuropathy requiring plasmapheresis, diverticulitis, 
hysterectomy, and diabetes. She had a CT scan that showed a 
small bowel obstruction with transition point in the left upper 
quadrant. She was made NPO, given IV fluids and admitted the 
floor hemodynamically stable for further management.

On HD1 she had flatus and a bowel movement. Her diet was 
advanced sequentially to regular with good tolerability. The 
patient voided without problem. During this hospitalization, the 
patient ambulated early and frequently, was adherent with 
respiratory toilet and incentive spirometry, and actively 
participated in the plan of care. The patient received 
subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this 
stay.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular 
diet, having bowel movements, ambulating, voiding without 
assistance, and pain was well controlled.  The patient was 
discharged home without services. The patient received discharge 
teaching and follow-up instructions with understanding 
verbalized and agreement with the discharge plan.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the Acute Care surgery service with 
abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. You had a CT scan that 
showed a small bowel obstruction. You were given IVF and managed 
non-operatively. You are now tolerating a regular diet and 
having bowel function. You are now ready to be discharged home 
to continue your recovery.

Please note the following discharge instructions:
Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

progressed proximally, decreased sensation, and paresthesias.  
She had extensive workup including sural nerve biopsy which 
showed severe loss of all fiber types and NCS showed severe 
sensory axonal polyneuropathy without myopathy. Labs sent 
including anti-Ro, anti-La, ___, HIV, Lyme, anti-IF 
were all negative and a clear etiology of her symptoms were not 
identified. Weakness has been felt to be reflective of sensory 
deafferentation. There have been numerous prior therapeutic
attempts including IVIG, which she did not respond to.  She has 
been more recently getting periodic plasmapheresis and this has 
helped her significantly.

Her last plasmapheresis was performed in ___. Course was 
complicated by partial SBO, managed conservatively with surgical 

consultation with NG tube to suction. The SBO resolved. She 
finished the 5 sessions of PLEX without event. Notably, she also 
has a history of coronary vasospasm that has occurred with PLEX. 
This was over ___ years ago. 

She was last seen in ___ at which point she complained 
of decreased sensation, particularly in her hands. She was 
dropping everything from her hands, knocking over objects if she 
doesn't look. In general, her hand dexterity was worse-even when 
she is watching what she is doing. She is now not walking at 
all. She got a new wheelchair. She has 7 aides that work with 
her at ___, but she finds this very overwhelming. She 
is transferring on her own but doesn't transfer by herself into 
or out of bed. She still needs help with dressing, showering, 
and hair. She is still having headaches. Other than the above, 
she noted diminished appetite. She is continuing to follow with 
her GI doctor and maintains some dietary restrictions; 
specifically, a low fiber/low residue diet with a regular bowel 
regimen. Onions and peppers are triggers and she mostly avoids 
vegetables. She does have some shortness of breath over the past 
year. She has occasional chest pain for which she uses 
nitroglycerin; she estimates taking this 3 times in the last 6 
months. She had an episode of dizziness, more described as a 
blurred vision. There were no other concerning neurologic 
symptoms at the time. The vision changes lasted about 1 hour. 

Due complaints of worsening sensory symptoms, she has agreed to 
admission for plasmapheresis. Upon arrival to ___, she

# Hypertensive crisis: 
Presented with headaches and nausea/vomiting with SBP > 200. 
Previously on BP agents but have been since discontinued with 
exception of Imdur (prescribed for coronary vasospasms). 
Required multiple IV agents in the ED but subsequently well 
managed on the floor with oral agents. Started on HCTZ 12.5 and 
amlodipine 5mg with significant improvement in blood pressures 
and resolution of associated symptoms. CT abd/pelvis obtained in 
setting of "LLQ" pain, notable for 4.4 cm heterogeneous right 
adrenal mass with foci of bulk fat, suggesting a myelolipoma, 
unchanged from prior imaging. Due to her markedly elevated BP 
and adrenal findings, secondary work up for HTN was initiated 
with plasma renin/aldosterone and metanephrines pending at the 
time of discharge. Due to stability of blood pressure, these 
results can be followed up as an outpatient.  Additionally on 
this admission, renal artery ultrasound was obtained but results 
limited as patient did not tolerate due to pain; the left kidney 
was not visualized and the right kidney had normal vascular wave 
form, lowering likelihood of RAS. Patient will need ongoing 
monitoring of blood pressure. If she continues to have 
intermittent episodes of severe hypertension, suspicion for 
pheochromocytoma would increase (unless pending plasma 
metanephrines results are reassuring). 
   
# Frontal headache: 
CT head without acute process (mass, bleed, etc). Markedly 
improved with treatment of HTN.

# Lateral hip/thigh pain: 
History and exam consistent with meralgia paresthetica and 
patients notes improvement with topical lidocaine patches. 
Prescription provided on discharge.

The patient was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service and 
was taken to the operating room for above described procedure. 
Please see separately dictated operative report for details. The 
surgery was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the 
procedure well. Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:
POD #1, patient had complained of burning sensation with void.  
Urinalysis was obtained which results were negative for urinary 
tract infection. Urine culture results were pending at the time 
of discharge and patient will be contacted if further treatment 
is needed.
POD #2, drain was discontinued. Patient cleared ___ without 
further issues.

Otherwise, pain was controlled with a combination of IV and oral 
pain medications.  The patient received Aspirin 81 mg twice 
daily for DVT prophylaxis starting on the morning of POD#1.  The 
surgical dressing will remain on until POD#7 after surgery. The 
patient was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs were checked 
throughout the hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the 
time of discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet and 
feeling well.  The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs. 
 The patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately 
controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was 
neurovascularly intact and the dressing was intact. 

The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as 
tolerated on the operative extremity.

condition.

Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.
 
2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills. 
 
3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.
 
4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.
 
5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon.
 
6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment in three (3) weeks.
 
7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, 
especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice 
directly on the skin. You may wrap the knee with an ace bandage 
for added compression. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal 
anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex, 
ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc) until cleared by 
your physician.
 
8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your Aspirin 81mg twice 
daily with food for four (4) weeks to help prevent deep vein 
thrombosis (blood clots).  Continue Pantoprazole daily while on 
Aspirin to prevent GI upset (x 4 weeks).  If you were taking 
Aspirin prior to your surgery, take it at 325 mg twice daily 
until the end of the 4 weeks, then you can go back to your 
normal dosing.
 
9. WOUND CARE: Please remove Aquacel dressing on POD#7 after 
surgery. It is okay to shower after surgery after 5 days but no 
tub baths, swimming, or submerging your incision until after 
your four (4) week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing 
on the wound after aqaucel is removed each day if there is 
drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. Check wound regularly 
for signs of infection such as redness or thick yellow drainage. 
 Staples will be removed by your doctor at follow-up appointment 
approximately 3 weeks after surgery.
 
10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, and wound checks.
 
11. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity. Mobilize with assistive devices (___) if 
needed. ___ brace locked in ___t all 
times. No strenuous exercise or heavy lifting until follow up 
appointment.

ED Course:
Seen in ED where X-ray revealed "a trimalleolar fracture with 
displaced fracture components and mild residual posterior 
subluxation of the talus with respect to the tibial plafond." 
Orthopedics consult was obtained and plan was determined for

Dear Ms. ___,

procedure. You have recovered well and the team believes you are

General instructions:
* Take your medications as prescribed.
* Do not drive while taking narcotics.
* Take a stool softener such as colace while taking narcotics to 
prevent constipation.
* Do not combine narcotic and sedative medications or alcohol.
* Do not take more than 4000mg acetaminophen (APAP) in 24 hrs.
* No strenuous activity until your post-op appointment.
* No heavy lifting of objects >10 lbs for 2 weeks.
* You may eat a regular diet.
* You may walk up and down stairs.

Incision care:
* You may shower and allow soapy water to run over incision; no 
scrubbing of incision. No bath tubs for 6 weeks.
* If you have steri-strips, leave them on. They will fall off on 
their own or be removed during your followup visit.

hospitalization sent to your doctor at home, call ___.

telemetry, for workup of worsened left-sided weakness.

corona radiata, in the same area as the previous stroke. This 
was thought to be stuttering of his orignial stroke, and his 
blood pressure medications were held for permissive 
hypertension. He was observed for several days, and his 
neurologic exam remained stable. He was therefore discharged off 
of his blood pressure medications, these will be added back on 
gradually at rehab. His LDL was low at 38, and so his 
atorvastatin was stopped.

Hepatitis panel was sent and was negative. Further workup was 
deferred to outpatient management.

add these back on gradually (one at a time) in two to three days 
time, with goal blood pressure 120-140.

Discharge Instructions:
These steps can help you recover after your procedure. 
DO drink plenty of water to flush out the bladder. 
DO avoid straining during a bowel movement. Eat 
fiber-containing foods and avoid foods that can cause 
constipation. Ask your doctor if you should take a laxative if 
you do become constipated. 
Don't take blood-thinning medications until your doctor says 
it's OK. 
Don't do any strenuous activity, such as heavy lifting, for 
four to six weeks or until your doctor says it's OK. 
Don't have sex. You'll likely be able to resume sexual 
activity in about four to six weeks. 
Don't drive until your doctor says it's OK. ___, you can 
drive once your catheter is removed and you're no longer taking 
prescription pain medications. 

You may continue to periodically see small amounts of blood in 
your urine--this is normal and will gradually improve. You may 
have clear or yellow urine that periodically turns pink/red 
throughout the healing process. Generally, the discoloration of 
the urine is OK unless it transitions from ___, 
___ Aid to a very dark, thick or like tomato juice 
color

Resume your pre-admission/home medications EXCEPT as noted. 
You should ALWAYS call to inform, review and discuss any 
medication changes and your post-operative course with your 
primary care team.  

Unless otherwise advised, blood thinning medications like 
ASPIRIN should be held until the urine has been clear/yellow for 
at least three days.  Your medication reconciliation will note 
if you may resume aspirin or prescription blood thinners (like 
Coumadin (warfarin), Xarelto, Lovenox, etc.)

If needed, you will be prescribed an antibiotic to continue 
after discharge or save until your Foley catheter is removed 
(called a trial of void or void trial).  

You may be discharged home with a medication called PYRIDIUM 
that will help with the "burning" pain you may experience when 
voiding. This medication may turn your urine bright orange.

Colace has been prescribed to avoid post surgical constipation 
and constipation related to narcotic pain medication. 
Discontinue if loose stool or diarrhea develops. Colace is a 
stool softener, NOT a laxative, and it is available 
over-the-counter 

AVOID STRAINING for bowel movements as this may stir up 
bleeding.  Avoid  constipating foods for ___ weeks, and drink 
plenty of fluids to keep hydrated

No vigorous physical activity or sports for 4 weeks or until 
otherwise advised

Do not lift anything heavier than a phone book (10 pounds) or 
participate in high intensity physical activity (which includes 
intercourse) for a minimum of four weeks or until you are 
cleared by your Urologist in follow-up

Acetaminophen (Tylenol) should be your first-line pain 
medication. A narcotic pain medication may also be prescribed 
for breakthrough or moderate pain.  

The maximum daily Tylenol/Acetaminophen dose is 3 grams from 
ALL sources. 

Do not drive or drink alcohol while taking narcotics and do 
not operate dangerous machinery.  

WHEN YOU ARE DISCHARGED WITH A FOLEY CATHETER:
o-Please also reference the nursing handout and instructions on 
routine care and hygiene

o-Your Foley should be secured to the catheter secure on your 
thigh at ALL times until your follow up with the surgeon.

o-DO NOT allow anyone outside your urologist/team 
representative remove your Foley for any reason.

o-Wear Large Foley bag for majority of time. The leg bag (if 
provided)  is for short-duration periods and the bag must be 
emptied frequently.

o-Do NOT drive if you have a Foley in place (for your 
safety-but of course you may be a passenger

Brief Hospital Course:
Patient is a ___ G1P1 admitted to obstetrics who delivered by 
primary low transverse cesarean for arrest of dilation and 
chorioamnionitis. Her intrapartum course was complicated by 
chorio, sepsis and post-partum hemorrhage.

For her chorioamnionitis and sepsis she was treated with 
Ampicillin, Gentamycin, and Clindamycin until 24 hours afebrile 
and clinically resolved. 

Regarding her postpartum hemorrhage, her intraoperative course 
was complicated by uterine atony and her total EBL was 1400cc. 
She was treated with 20units of pitocin, cytotec, methergine and 
hemabate intraoperatively with resolution of her atony. Please 
see operative report for full details. Post-operatively her 
hematocrit nadired at 21.1 on POD#2 and she received 1 unitPRBC 
for symptomatic blood loss anemia. Her post-transfusion hct was 
24.9 and her symptoms were improved.

The remainder of her postpartum course was uncomplicated and she 
was felt to be safe to be discharged to home on ___.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to the Acute Care Surgery on ___ with 
abdominal pain and found to have a perforated appendicitis. You 
were treated with antibiotics. An ___ drain was placed to help 
manage a localized abscess (bacterial collection). 

You are now safe for discharge. You should take the prescribed 
antibiotics for 8 more days. 

You should follow up with the Acute Care Service in ___ weeks. 
You need to empty your drain on a daily basis. A ___ nurse has 
been arranged to visit you at home to help with this. 

Drain Care:

 *Please look at the site every day for signs of infection 
(increased redness or pain, swelling, odor, yellow or bloody 
discharge, warm to touch, fever).

 *Maintain suction of the bulb.

 *Note color, consistency, and amount of fluid in the drain. 
Call the doctor, ___, or ___ nurse if the amount 
increases significantly or changes in character.

 *Be sure to empty the drain frequently. Record the output, if 
instructed to do so.

 *You may shower; wash the area gently with warm, soapy water.

 *Keep the insertion site clean and dry otherwise.

 *Avoid swimming, baths, hot tubs; do not submerge yourself in 
water.

 *Make sure to keep the drain attached securely to your body to 
prevent pulling or dislocation.

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:

 *You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.

 *New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.

 *If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.

 *You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, 
diarrhea, or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry 
mouth, rapid heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.

 *You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.

 *You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.

 *You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.

 *Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o M w/ recent hospitalization for 
perforated appendicitis managed non-operatively w/ ___ drain 
placement who is presented to ___ this admission with 
worsening abdominal pain and diarrhea.  After first hospital 
discharge, his ___ cultures resulted growing MDR E. coli and 
Shigella. The E. coli was
resistant to augmentin, which he was d/c'd on, and was thus 
switched to Bactrim. On this admission, labs showed WBC 16.2, Cr 
1.4, and lactate 2.2, and a CT A/P showed interval decrease in 
RLQ abscess cavity.  Stool studies and RPR were sent.  He was 
started on Bactrim DS 2 tabs PO BID + metronidazole 500 mg PO 
TID.  ID was consulted and recommended extending the antibiotic 
duration to 4 days beyond drain removal. Stool study later came 
back indicating that shigella was resistant to Bactrim.  Given 
that there was shigella in the ___ fluid collection which was 
sensitive to Bactrim, the patient remained on Bactrim, 
metronidazole and was also started on cefpodoxime.  

The patient's bowel movements became more formed during his 
hospital stay.  His ___ drain was removed on ___ as there was 
no fluid coming from the drain. At the time of discharge, the 
patient was doing well, afebrile and hemodynamically stable.  
The patient was tolerating a diet, ambulating, voiding without 
assistance, and pain was well controlled.  The patient received 
discharge teaching and follow-up instructions with understanding 
verbalized and agreement with the discharge plan.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain and 
diarrhea and were found to have inflammation of part of your 
colon. The fluid from your abscess grew out bacteria including 
Escherichia coli, Shigella sonnei and Bacteroides fragilis.  You 
were initially kept on the antibiotic, Bactrim (sulfamethoxazole 
and trimethoprim), to treat both the Shigella and E. coli.  You 
were also started on another antibiotic, called Flagyl 
(metronidazole) to treat the Bacteroides.  A stool sample was 
sent while you were in the hospital which again showed shigella, 
but the shigella was resistant to Bactrim.  Therefore, you were 
started on a new antibiotic, called Cefpodoxime to treat the 
shigella.   Your abdominal drain was ultimately removed and you 
will continue on oral antibiotics for an additional 4 (four) 
days.

You are now ready to be discharged home.  Please note the 
following discharge instructions:

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:

*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain in not improving within ___ hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse or changes location or moving to your chest or 
back.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.

Please resume all regular home medications, unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

Incision Care:
*Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have 
increased pain, swelling, redness, or drainage from the incision 
site.
*Avoid swimming and baths until your follow-up appointment.
*You may shower, and wash surgical incisions with a mild soap 
and warm water. Gently pat the area dry.

He was directly admitted from clinic for monitoring and repeat 
lab work. The Infectious disease team and Hematology were 
consulted for evaluation of his thrombocytopenia. Infectious 
disease believed that his anti-biotic regimen may be the 
etiology of his thrombocytopenia, but since his previous 
infection had been resolved they did not feel he would need any 
further antibiotics. 

Hematology also evaluated the patient and believed that the most 
likely etiology is medication induced thrombocytopenia from his 
antibiotic regimen. They also considered autoimmune 
thrombocytopenia, or pseudo-thrombocytopenia. They recommended 
continuing to monitor his platelet count and if it continued to 
trend in the right direction he would be appropriate for 
discharge with follow up and a repeat CBC. 

On the morning of discharge the patient continued to show 
improvement in his platelet number (___). He was tolerating a 
regular diet, was in no pain, was independently ambulatory. He 
was given appropriate follow up appointments as well as a 
laboratory requisition for follow up CBC and electrolytes which 
should be collected ___ days following discharge per hematology 
recommendations. The patient expressed good understanding of 
these instructions and was discharged home in good condition.

# Strep viridans bacteremia: The patient initially presented to 
the ___ with R arm cellulitis on ___, was treated with Keflex 
and discharged, and was then called to return when one blood 
culture bottle from ___ grew Strep viridans. She was noted 
to have a new systolic murmur. She was started on ceftriaxone 
and daily surveillance blood cultures remained negative. She 
remained afebrile. A TTE was normal with no valvular 
abnormalities or evidence of endocarditis. She was seen by the 
Infectious Disease service, who felt that in light of the 
patient's clinical stability and negative subsequent blood 
cultures, the initial positive blood culture may have reflected 
contamination from the patient's skin rather than a true 
bloodstream infection. Antibiotics were discontinued with a plan 
for outpatient followup and repeat blood cultures 1 week after 
discharge.

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions
 
Elective Aneurysm Clipping
 
Call your neurosurgeons office and speak to the Nurse 
Practitioner if you experience:

 

-     Any neurological issues, such as change in vision, speech 
or movement

 

-     Swelling, drainage, or redness of your incision

 

-     Any problems with medications, such as nausea vomiting or 
lethargy

 

-     Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit

 

-     Headaches not relieved with prescribed medications

 

Activity:

 

-     Start to resume all activities as you tolerate  but start 
slowly and increase at your own pace.

 

-     Do not operate any motorized vehicle for at least 10 days 
after your surgery  your Nurse Practitioner can give you more 
detail at the time of your suture removal.  

 

Incision Care:

 

-     Keep your wound clean and dry.

 

-     Do not use shampoo until your sutures are removed. 

 

-     When you are allowed to shampoo your hair, let the shampoo 
run off the incision line.  Gently pad the incision with a towel 
to dry.

 

-     Do not rub, scrub, scratch, or pick at any scabs on the 
incision line.

 

-     You need your sutures removed 7 to 10 days after surgery

 

 

 

Post-Operative Experiences: Physical

 

-     Jaw pain on the same side as your surgery; this goes away 
after about a month

 

-     You may experience constipation.  Constipation can be 
prevented by:

 

o     Drinking plenty of fluids

o     Increasing fiber in your diet by eating vegetables, 
prunes, fiber rich breads and cereals, or fiber supplements

o     Exercising

o     Using over-the-counter bowel stimulants or laxatives as 
needed, stopping usage if you experience loose bowel movements 
or diarrhea

 

-     Fatigue which will slowly resolve over time

 

-     Numbness or tingling in the area of the incision; this can 
take weeks or months to fully resolve

 

-     Muffled hearing in the ear near the incision area

 

-     Low back pain or shooting pain down the leg which can 
resolve with increased activity

 

Post-Operative Experiences: Emotional

 

-     You may experience depression.  Symptoms of depression can 
include

 

o     Feeling down or sad

o     Irritability, frustration, and confusion

o     Distractibility

o     Lower Self-Esteem/Relationship Challenges

o     Insomnia

o     Loneliness

 

-     If you experience these symptoms, you can contact your 
Primary Care Provider who can make a referral to a Psychologist 
or Psychiatrist

 

-     You can also seek out a local Brain Aneurysm Support Group 
in your area through the Brain Aneurysm Foundation

 

o     More information can be found at ___

stability. IP is planning on doing a lung biopsy tentatively on

#Chest pain: As noted above, patient presented with burning 
chest pain, worse after eating, and was noted to have TWI in

revealed a severe fixed defect involving the inferior wall and 
apical portion of the myocardium. It also showed a moderate 
hypokinesis of the inferior wall and apex. Findings consistent 
with likely old MI. He was continued on his home aspirin and 
statin. He was discharged on Metoprolol 12.5mg, which should be

Brief Hospital Course:
___ with past medical history notable for AF, diet controlled 
DM, hypothyroidism, and recent UTI treatment p/w 2wk h/o 
worsening SOB, productive cough, subjective fever and chills and 
dysuria, malodorous urine.

#  SHORTNESS OF BREATH
Patient was diagnosed with pneumonia given the constellation of 
symptoms involving initially non-productive to productive cough, 
worsening shortness of breath, chest tightness, subjective fever 
or chills, and malaise. CXR shows bilateral interstitial 
thickening and possible RLL involvement. Influenza swaps were 
negative. Patient was treated with azithromycin and ceftriaxone 
and then switched to levofloxacin. She remained afebrile and 
hemodynamically stable. Her respiratory status improved upon 
antibiotics administration. She gradually came off O2 
supplement. Her leukocytosis resolved. Her ambulatory O2 sat was 
95% on RA. She was discharged with the plan to complete the 
total 7day course of antibiotics. 
.
# diarrhea: Patient developed loose stools a couple of days 
prior to discharge.  It was thought this was due to the 
antibiotics as her cdiff was negative. She was given immodium 
and it improved.
.
# UTI
She presented with dysuria, malodorous urine, and microscopic 
urine exam notable for increased WBC and few bacteria. UCx was 
positive for pan-sensitive E.coli. She was treated with azithro 
+ ceftriaxone initially and switched to levofloxacin as above. 
.
# ANEMIA
Per OMR, she had significant Hct drop from 41 to 30 over the 3 
month period since ___. There was no evidence of active 
bleeding. Guaic was neg. Normocytic with inappropriate rectic 
with nl iron study/folate/B12 was consistent with anemia of 
chronic illness. Her Hct remained stable.
.
# ELEVATED INR
She presented with INR of 5.4. Coumadin was held initially. It 
was restarted at 2mg once her INR came close to her target range 
of ___ (Please see the lab section). She was discharged on 2mg 
coumadin with the instruction to get her INR checked on ___ at 
the ___ clinic.
.
# NEW DIASTOLIC LV DYSFUNCTION
Echocardiogram revealed new grade II diastolic LV dysfunction. 
There however was no evidence of pulmonary edema throughout the 
___ hospital course. She was recommended to start taking 
lisinopril 2.5mg daily upon discharge and follow up with PCP.
.
#  SWALLOWING DIFFICULTY
She developed a sudden difficulty swallowing her pill on 
hospital day #2. Speech and Swallow consult was made. It was 
thought to be functional difficulty. It resolved spontaneously 
within hours. 
.

#  Hearing difficulty
She developed sudden onset hearing diminishment and crackles on 
hospital day 2. There was no evidence of infection upon exam. It 
was thought to be related to her current PNA/URI. Patient 
requested an ENT follow up arrangement upon discharge.

# Chronic Atrial Fibrillation 
Patient remained hemodynamically stable on coumadin throughout 
the course

# Diabetes Mellitus
Glucose was well controlled in insulin sliding scale. 
.  
# Hypothyroidism: 
She continued on outpatient levothyroxine regimen.

Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the ___ for pneumonia and urinary tract 
infection on ___. 

Your breathing improved quickly with the antibiotics

levofloxacin). By the time of your discharge, you were able to 
breath well without oxygen supplement and walk around without 
any difficulty. 

The burning sensation you had with urinating also resolved 
quickly upon treatment with the above antibiotics. Your blood 
culture was pending at the time of discharge. Please follow up 
on this with your PCP.

You unfortunately developed diarrhea. We think this is related 
to the antibiotics given to treat pneumonia and urinary tract 
infection. You tested negative for C. difficile. We started you 
on anti-diarrheal agent prior to discharge. You can take 2mg 
after each loose stool until you feel better. Diarrhea should 
resolve once you complete your last dose of antibiotics on ___. 
You should continue to drink plenty of fluids to avoid becoming 
dehydrated.

You also developed some congestion involving both of your ears 
with some minor hearing diminishement. There was no evidence of 
active infection in your ears. We think this is related to your 
ongoing pneumonia and prior upper respiratory tract infection. 
We have scheduled an appointment with the ear nose throat 
specialist.

and decreased the dose to 2mg. It came down to the target range 
___ (3.1 on ___ by the time of your discharge. You should have 
INR rechecked on ___.

from your last blood count measured in ___. The tests 
we ordered were all fine (iron study, folate, B12). You did not 
have blood in your stool. You should follow up with your PCP on 
this issue.

with your heart relaxation (left ventricular diastolic 
dysfunction), but you did not have any complication related to 
this during this hospital stay. We started you on a new 
medication called lisinopril, which is known to be beneficial in 
this condition. You should follow up with PCP on this issue and 
have your labs checked within 2 weeks.

the medicine you should take at home. If a medication that you 
normally take is not on the list or a medication that you do not 
take is on the list please discuss it with the team! 

It is very important that you take Aspirin every day! You 
should never stop this medication before checking with your 
surgeon. You also will take Plavix (clopidrogel) everyday for 
the next ___ days

Pain Management:
It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following surgery. 
This pain is often described as soreness. 
You may take Tylenol (acetaminophen ) as needed for pain. You 
will also receive a prescription for stronger pain medicine, if 
the Tylenol doesnt work, take prescription medicine. 
Narcotic pain medication can be very constipating, please also 
take a stool softner such as Colace. If constipation becomes a 
problem, your pharmacist can suggest additional over the counter 
medications. 
Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your 
pain gets to severe. 
Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain is 
getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon. 

 Activity:
 Please wear appropriate shoes when bearing weight on Right leg 
with  charcot foot 
Walking is good because it helps your muscles get stronger and 
improves blood flow. Start with short walks. If you can, go a 
little further each time, letting comfort be your guide. 
Try not to go up and downstairs too much in the first weeks. 
Use stairs only once or twice a day until your incision is fully 
healed and you are back to your usual strength.
Avoid things that may constrict blood flow or put pressure on 
your incision, such as tight shoes, socks or knee highs.
Do not take a tub bath or swim until your staples are removed 
and your wound is healed. 
When you sit, keep your leg elevated to reduce swelling.
If swelling in your leg is getting worse, lie down with your 
leg up on a pillows. If your swelling continues, please call 
your surgeon. You may be instructed to use special elastic 
bandages or stockings.
Try not to sit in the same position for a long while. For 
example, ___ go on a long car ride. 
You may go outside. But avoid traveling long distances until 
you see your surgeon at your next visit. 
You may resume sexual activity after your incisions are well 
healed.

Your incision

Your incision may be slightly red around the stitches or 
staples. This is normal.
It is normal to have a small amount of clear or light red fluid 
coming from your incision.

 This will decrease and stop in a few days. If it does not stop, 
or if you have a lot of fluid coming out., please call your 
surgeon.
You may shower 48 hours after your surgery. Do not let the 
shower spray right on the incision, Let the soapy water run over 
the incision, then rinse. Gently pat the area dry. Do not scrub 
the incision, Do not apply ointment or lotions to the incision.
You do not need to cover the incision if there is no drainage, 
If there is a small amount of drainage, put a small sterile 
gauze or Bandaid over the incison.
It is normal to feel a firm ridge along the incision, This will 
go away as your wound heals. 
Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area for 6 months. 
This will help keep the scar from becoming discolored.
Over ___ months, your incision will fade and become less 
prominent.

Diet and Bowels
It is normal to have a decreased appetite. Your appetite will 
return over time. Follow a well-balanced, health healthy diet, 
without too much salt and fat. 
Prescription pain medicine might make you constipated. If 
needed, you may take a stool softener (such as Colace) or gentle 
laxative (ask your pharmacist for recommendations).

 Drinking more fluid may also help.
If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or having pain 
moving your bowels, call your primary care physician.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,
You were hospitalized due to symptoms of right sided weakness 
and trouble speaking resulting from an ACUTE ISCHEMIC STROKE, a 
condition where a blood vessel providing oxygen and nutrients to 
the brain is blocked by a clot. The brain is the part of your 
body that controls and directs all the other parts of your body, 
so damage to the brain from being deprived of its blood supply 
can result in a variety of symptoms.
Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for 
medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. 
In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk 
factors. Your risk factors are:
high cholesterol
narrowing of the blood vessels in the brain
PFO (patent foramen ovale- a connection between two chambers in 
the heart)
We are changing your medications as follows:
Aspirin 81 mg daily
Atorvastatin 80 mg daily
Please take your other medications as prescribed.

Please follow up with Neurology and your primary care physician 
as listed below. You will need to call to schedule this 
appointment once you have active insurance. 

If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek 
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical 
Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, 
please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of 
these symptoms:
- Sudden partial or complete loss of vision
- Sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth
- Sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to 
you
- Sudden weakness of one side of the body
- Sudden drooping of one side of the face
- Sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body

Sincerely,
Your ___ Neurology Team

Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,

___ was a pleasure taking care of you here at ___ 
___! You came to the hospital after you 
fell while preparing for your colonoscopy. Our imaging studies 
showed that you had a fracture of your neck, more specifically 
the vertebrae labeled, C2-C3 and upper back, the vertebrae 
labeled T1-T2. 

While you were in the hospital, you intermittently had a fast 
irregular heart rate called atrial fibrillation. While you were 
having the a.fib, you did not have any symptoms of chest pain or 
palpitations. We did not change your medications for fear that 
your heart rate would be too slow. From talking with you, you 
seemed to have talked with your cardiologists about coumadin to 
thin your blood because atrial fibrillation puts you at 
increased risk for stroke. We continued you on aspirin 325.

The following are recommendations from the neurosurgeons who saw 
you while in the hospital.
Do not smoke.
No pulling up, lifting more than 10 lbs., or excessive bending 
or twisting.
Limit your use of stairs to ___ times per day.
You are required to wear your cervical collar at all times.
You may shower briefly without the collar or back brace; 
unless you have been instructed otherwise.
Take your pain medication as instructed; you may find it best 
if taken in the morning when you wake-up for morning stiffness, 
and before bed for sleeping discomfort.
Do not take any anti-inflammatory medications such as Motrin, 
Advil, Aspirin, and Ibuprofen etc. unless directed by your 
doctor.
Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as pain medicine 
(narcotics) can cause constipation. We recommend taking an over 
the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) while 
taking narcotic pain medication.
Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at 
your post-operative office visit.

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING:

Pain that is continually increasing or not relieved by pain 
medicine.
Any weakness, numbness, tingling in your extremities.
Fever greater than or equal to 10.5 F. 
Any change in your bowel or bladder habits (such as loss of 
bowl or urine control).

need to be on blood thinners. 

We also took a picture of your head and you were not having any 
bleeding in the brain making us pretty sure that you did not 
have a stroke.  However, you will have follow-up with Cognitive 
Neurology to assess the cause and extent of your memory 
impairment.

While in the hospital you had blood in your urine.  This was 
evaluated by the kidney doctors and repeat tests of your urine 
showed improved kidney function and less blood in the urine.  
However, you should be followed-up as an outpatient by a Kidney 
specialist.

You worked with Physical Therapy while in the hospital and your 
COPD treatment was continued.  You oxygen levels were low while 
you walked and it was recommended that you be discharged to a 
Rehabilitation Hospital where you can continue to get physical 
therapy while your lungs recover.

Please see below for your follow-up appointments.

It was a pleasure caring for you and we wish you a speedy 
recovery.

for takotsobu's cardiomyopathy complicated by spontaneous rectus 
sheath and retroperitoneal hematoma, presenting from OSH after 
suffering bilateral PEs in the setting of treatment for LLE 
cellulitis and postobstructive pneumonia.

# Pulmonary Emboli:  Patient acutely decompensated on ___ ___ngio consistent with bilateral PEs.  Source was unclear as 
bilateral LENIs were negative.  Likely represented provoked PE 
in the setting of infection and prolonged hospitalization.  
Patient was started on a heparin drip with target PTT 60-80.  
Once she was therapeutic, coumadin was started.  The heparin 
drip was discontinued after 24h overlap of being therapeutic on 
coumadin.  Patient is being discharged on a coumadin schedule of 
2 mg ___ and 4 mg ___.  She will have her 
INR followed by her PCP, ___ draw on ___.

# Pneumonia:  Patient transferred from OSH with CT thorax with 
findings concerning for postobstructive pneumonia.  She was 
started on IV Vanc/zosyn empirically on ___.  IV Vanc and 
Zosyn were continued in house for a total of 8 days of therapy.  
She remained afebrile, without a white count, and her 
respiratory status remained stable and she was breathing 
comfortably on 2 liters NC on day of discharge.  She will 
continue to need vancomycin 750 mg Q12H through her PICC for 
cellulitis.

# Rectus sheath and pelvic hematoma: Spontaneously occured 
during systemic anticoagulation for takotsubo (which has since 
resolved on repeat ECHO).  ACS consulted on prior admission in 
___ and recommended trending hematocrit, has been stable on 
all recent imaging.  Her coagulation parameters were closely 
monitored and hematocrits remain stable this admission.  Patient 
was given the warning signs to look out for during the next ___ 
months as she is on anticoagulation including sudden worsening 
abdominal pain and new bruising or bleeding, in which case she 
should call her physician.

# Cellulitis: Prior LENIs negative for DVT.  Likely staph.  Was 
initially on IV Vanc then switched to Ancef.  Placed back on IV 
vanc on ___ and this was continued this hospitalization.  
Patient's redness and swelling was much improved.  She will need 
to complete a 14 day course of vancomycin (last day ___ 
through her ___ line.  

# COPD:  Patient's breathing was at or near baseline during 
admission.  At times she felt somewhat short of breath and 
requested standing nebulizer treatments.  She remains satting 
well on 2L NC and in no distress at the time of this writing.  
Her home medications in addition to nebulizers are being 
continued.

# Hematuria: patient has had hematuria since prior 
hospitalization thought provoked by traumatic foley in the 
setting of anticoagulation.  Prior cytology negative.  Urology 
was consulted and recommended outpatient f/u unless starts 
passing clots.  Her urine remained dark brown throughout 
hospitalization without any evidence of clots.  She continued to 
be incontient despite detrol.  She has an appointment scheduled 
with urology for further management of this problem.

# Dilated CBD: Incidentally found on CT imaging for her PE.

resolve.

Brief Hospital Course:
# Unstable angina
Patient with history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia 
presenting with resting chest, arm, and jaw pain, found to have 
t-wave inversions on EKG consistent with unstable angina. 
Managed medically until catheterization on day of admission, 
which revealed 80-90% left anterior descending artery stenosis, 
90% left circumflex stenosis, and 90% right coronary artery 
stenosis. Drug-eluting stent was placed in the left anterior 
descending without complications. Procedure was well tolerated 
and symptoms improved. Patient was discharged on aspirin, 
statin, Plavix, metoprolol. Will have cardiology ___ 
___. 

# Hypertension
Discontinued atenolol, hydrochlorothiazide. Started on 
metoprolol at discharge.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were hospitalized due to symptoms of difficulty forming 
words, tingling in your hands, resulting from an ACUTE CEREBRAL 
HEMORRHAGE, which is a small area of bleeding in your brain. The 
brain is the part of your body that controls and directs all the 
other parts of your body, so damage bleeding in the brain can 
result in a variety of symptoms.

Cerebral hemorrhage can have many different causes. In your case 
it could have resulted from small trauma to your head that you 
suffered several days ago. In addition, you might have an 
underlying condition called cerebral amyloid angiopathy which is 
common in your age group and predisposes to bleeding. However, 
your MRI of your brain did not show any obvious evidence of 
this. 

We are changing your medications as follows:
 1) please STOP Plavix (clopidigrel)
 2) please restart your aspirin one week after discharge 
(___)

Please take your other medications as prescribed.
Please follow up with your doctors as listed below.

If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek 
emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical 
Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, 
please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of 
these symptoms:
 - Sudden partial or complete loss of vision  
 - Sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth  
 - Sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to 
you  
 - Sudden weakness of one side of the body  
 - Sudden drooping of one side of the face  
 - Sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body  

Sincerely,  
Your ___ Neurology Team

workup. ENT was consulted for input and audiology evaluation. 
Patient underwent audiology testing on ___ which demonstrated 
that the patient has profound hearing loss in the left ear and 
moderate hearing loss in the right ear. Due to concern of 
location of the tumor and secondary deficits in swallow, SLP was 
consulted who downgraded diet. Surgical Options were discussed 
with the family and it was decided to proceed with surgical 
tumor resection/debulking. In preparation for surgery, CTA head 
and neck was done to evaluate for compression of vertebral 
arteries. On ___, the patient underwent a Video Swallow 
pre-operatively for a baseline evaluation. Her neuro exam 
remained stable, and she was changed to floor status while 
awaiting surgical plan. On ___ she was noted to have horizontal 
gaze restriction bilaterally with generalized weakness worse on 
her lower extremities. She was started on decadron with insulin 
sliding scale and GI prophylaxis. Patient was brought to the OR 
on ___ for Stage 1 of two-part surgical series. On ___, she 
underwent neuronavigated left craniotomy combined extended 
middle fossa approach and translabrinthe approach to skull base 
with placement of right frontal EVD; this Stage 1 was primarily 
done for bone work while Stage II was planned for further tumor 
resection. She also underwent diagnostic cerebral angiogram ___ 
to evaluate the cavernous sinus and aterial supply. Both 
procedures were uncomplicated. See operative note for further 
detail. Patient remained intubated postoperatively and was 
admitted to the Neuro ICU for close monitoring. Postoperative 
NCHCT revealed adequate placement of EVD and expected 
postsurgical changes. On ___, the patient went back to the OR 
for Stage II neuronavigated left craniotomy combined extended 
middle fossa approach and translabrinthe approach to skull base 
for tumor resection. Stage II was an extensively long surgery 
but otherwise uncomplicated. Please see dedicated operative note 
for further detail. Patient remained intubated postoperatively 
and returned to the Neuro ICU for further care. An abdominal 
drain was left in place that was then discontinued on POD#2 
(___). Postop NCHCT with expected postsurgical changes. She was 
extubated on ___. Following the stage II procedure, she had a 
notable left facial and left CNVII weakness for which ENT 
evaluated her. She was put on Dexamethasone 10mg Q8hrs x 3 doses 
before her Dex was decreased back down to 4mg Q8hrs. Insulin 
sliding scale was increased for elevated blood sugars. Given the 
location of the lesion, the left facial weakness was not a 
surprising post-operative finding and no STAT imaging was 
performed. Following the resection, her EVD was kept at 10 above 
the tragus, and raised to 20 on ___ and clamped on ___. 
Patient with AMS and increased ICPs, CTH on ___ revealed 
hydrocephalus and the EVD was opened to 15 above the tragus. 
Patient with increased pain on ___ and low dose oxycodone was 
added for pain relief. CTH in AM on ___ revealed stable size of 
ventricles, residual meningioma, SAH, SDH and IVH with decreased 
size of extra axial fluid collection. EVD was clamped again on 
___ however, due to ICP sustained in ___ and need for 
trach/PEG placement, the decision was made to re-open the EVD on 
___ at 15 above the tragus. VPS placement was put on hold 
pending trach/PEG placement. PEG was placed at bedside on ___. 
On ___ patient was noted to have a hematoma at the abdominal 
fat graft site. Patient underwent an ultrasound on ___ evening 
which revealed a hematoma and a repeat ultrasound was 
recommended if hematoma did not clear clinically. Patient 
continued to be monitored closely, there were no signs of 
infection and hematoma remained stable to improved. On ___, a 
one-week wean to off of the Decadron was initiated. Patient had 
a trach and VP shunt placement on ___. Please see OMR for 
operative reports for more information. VPS was set to 1.0. 
Patient was quickly weaned to trach mask and called out to the 
NIMU. She remained neurologically stable in the NIMU. She was 
made floor status on ___. She continued to remain neurologically 
stable on the floor. Her staples from her VPS insertion were 
removed on POD 10. At the time of staple removal, the incision 
was well-approximated without any active drainage or signs of 
infection. Patient's neuro exam continued to improve through 
remainder of admission. On day of discharge, she is speaking and 
alert/oriented x 2, she is following commands and moving all 
extremities.

hospital. She had intermittent runs of SVT, but multiple EKGs

SLP evaluated the patient for dysphagia postoperatively. The

titrated to goal. On day of discharge, SLP determined that she

unresponsive with LUE rhythmic twitching. A STAT NCHCT was 
stable. She was loaded with Keppra and placed on EEG. EEG was

recommended stopping duonebs and giving guafenesin and chest ___

from Vancomycin to Nafcillin for proper coverage. Patient

___, patient self discontinued her trach. She tolerated on room 
air without any signs of respiratory distress. However, ACS team 
was consulted and felt that given she had a size 8 trach in

size. Trach was replaced with smaller size and with a red cap 
on. Patient tolerated well. She was decannulated on ___ which

Patient with chronic right knee pain and secondary right leg

Discharge Instructions:
Discharge Instructions
Brain Tumor

Surgery:
- You underwent surgery to remove a brain lesion from your 
brain. 
- You had a VP shunt placed for hydrocephalus. 
- Your shunt is a ___ Strata Valve which is programmable. 
This will need to be readjusted after all MRIs or exposure to 
large magnets.  Your shunt is programmed to 1.0.
- All of your surgical staples have been removed. 
- You may shower at this time but keep your incision as dry as 
possible until fully healed.
- It is best to keep your incision open to air but it is ok to 
cover it when outside. 
- Call your surgeon if there are any signs of infection like 
redness, fever, or drainage. 

Activity:
- We recommend that you avoid heavy lifting, running, climbing, 
or other strenuous exercise until your follow-up appointment.
- You make take leisurely walks and slowly increase your 
activity at your own pace once you are symptom free at rest. 
___ try to do too much all at once.
- No driving while taking any narcotic or sedating medication. 
- If you experienced a seizure while admitted, you are NOT 
allowed to drive by law. 
- No contact sports until cleared by your neurosurgeon. You 
should avoid contact sports for 6 months. 

Medications:
- Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, 
Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. 
- You have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam). This 
medication helps to prevent seizures. Please continue this 
medication as indicated on your discharge instruction. It is 
important that you take this medication consistently and on 
time. 
- You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if 
you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication.

What You ___ Experience:
- You may experience headaches and incisional pain. 
- You may also experience some post-operative swelling around 
your face and eyes. This is normal after surgery and most 
noticeable on the second and third day of surgery.  You apply 
ice or a cool or warm washcloth to your eyes to help with the 
swelling. The swelling will be its worse in the morning after 
laying flat from sleeping but decrease when up. 
- You may experience soreness with chewing. This is normal from 
the surgery and will improve with time. Softer foods may be 
easier during this time. 
- Feeling more tired or restlessness is also common.
- Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and 
eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription 
pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener.

When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for:
- Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision 
site. 
- Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit
- Nausea and/or vomiting
- Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake
- Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers
- Seizures
- Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak
- Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg

Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience 
any of the following:
- Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg
- Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding
- Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or 
coordination
- Sudden severe headaches with no known reason

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient presented Dr. ___ on ___ with very

Given the findings, the patient was admitted to ___ and made NPO 
and given IV fluids. She was placed on IV Cipro and Zosyn. CT 
abdomen pelvis revealed a phlegmon in the left pericolonic 
region and inflammation of the surround muscle and soft tissue. 
Decision was made to take her to the OR the follow day.  She 
underwent a sigmoid colectomy and ___ procedure on ___. 
She tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to the 
floor after an uneventful stay in the PACU.  Her pain was 
initially managed with PCA. The ostomy was pink and robust, she 
began to tolerate sips on POD1. We slowly advanced her to clears 
on POD2, her foley was also DC'd and she voided without issue. 
Previous LLQ erythema significantly resolved. Her bowel funciton 
was slow to return. We switched her to oral pain regimen on 
___. Her pain was controlled with relatively small amount of 
narcotics, was OOB and ambulating. She finally passed flatus on 
___, we advanced diet as tolerated to regular. Antibiotics were 
discontinued on the same day.  We digitized the stoma and found 
a hard stool ball. We instilled mineral oil through the ostomy 
several days in a row and provided her with an oral bowel 
regimen.  She had small amount of stool output on ___. She was
