Discharge Instructions:
- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- WBAT

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take Coumadin per your usual home dosing. Please bridge 
with Lovenox and discontinue lovenox 24 hours after INR is 2.0 

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Please remain in your dressing and do not change unless it is 
visibly soaked or falling off.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

FOLLOW UP:
Please follow up with your Orthopaedic Surgeon, Dr. ___. 
You will have follow up with ___, NP in the 
Orthopaedic Trauma Clinic 14 days post-operation for evaluation. 
Call ___ to schedule appointment upon discharge.

Please follow up with your primary care doctor regarding this 
admission within ___ weeks and for and any new 
medications/refills.

WBAT right lower extremity, activity as tolerated right lower 
extremity.
Treatments Frequency:
Please change dressings as needed with gauze and paper tape. 
DC staples at 2 weeks.

# Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting: Presentation initially 
concerning for partial SBO although abdominal xray and CT did 
not support this diagnosis. A U/A was negative. She was made 
NPO, including meds; an NGT was placed overnight (___), 
drained bilious material and was subsequently removed ___ per 
pt request. Pt evaluated by bariatric surgery who did not see 
any indication for surgery. Had EGD and EUS ___ (prior to 
admission) that showed mild esophagitis, small remnant stomach 
with  gastrojejunal anastamosis, erythema in the stomach, 
dilated pancreatic duct, normal pancreas/pancreatic vasculature. 
 Also had MRCP in ___ with recommended repeat MRCP in ___ 
mos. Most likely etiology of abdominal pain/nausea/vomiting is 
constipation, which may have been precipitated by methadone 
abuse in outpatient setting. Of note, PCP conveyed concern about 
possible methadone abuse.  Ddx includes referred pain from known 
esophagitis vs marginal ulcer at gastrojejunal anastamosis vs 
malingering. Given reassuring exam, labs and imaging, we managed 
medically with pantoprazole BID, standing tylenol and home 
methadone 7.5mg PO TID for pain, and an aggressive bowel regimen 
(senna, colace, miralax, bisacodyl, enema). She was given zofran 
and compazine for nausea with good relief. She was intially made 
NPO, transitioned to clears on ___, and to regular diet on 
___. EKG ___ showed QTc 448 (methadone, zofran can prolong 
QT). EKG ___ with QTc 426. She was weaned to methadone 5mg 
TID and discharged on this dose.

taken any extra meds. Neuro exam was then normal. Room search 
initiated w/no meds found.  Her AM gabapentin, seroquel and 
clonazepam were held. The following AM, she was lethargic, 
slurring her words, unable to fully open eyes, pinpoint pupils.  
Told her we were going to give narcan.  By the time we returned 
to the room 10 minutes later, she was awake, angry about mention 
of narcan, pupils 2mm and reactive.  Concerning for neurologic 
abnormality vs seizure vs pseudoseizure vs taking medications we 
are not administering. CT head was negative for acute 
abnormalities.  Compazine was discontinued as this was the only 
new medication we had started.  Methadone was decreased from 
home dose of 7.5 mg TID to 5mg TID. She was monitored on 
telemetry for > 24 hrs with no other episodes.
.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear ___,

___ was a pleasure taking care of you at ___.  You were 
admitted for nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain.  This was 
initially concerning for a possible small bowel obstruction, but 
an abdominal xray and abdominal cat scan did not show any 
evidence of obstruction.  Bariatric surgery evaluated you and 
recommended medical management. The most likely cause of your 
nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain is severe constipation.  
Your symptoms improved with anti-nausea medications and an 
aggressive bowel regimen.  As we discussed, methadone and other 
opiate medications (such as dilaudid, morphine, oxycodone) 
frequently cause constipation.  We encourage you to work with 
Dr. ___ to decrease the amount of methadone you take at 
home. We have prescibed several medications to help with your 
constipation.  We recommend that you use senna, colace and 
miralax daily.  The bisacodyl (by mouth and/or per rectum) and 
the fleet enema should be used only if you become constipated. 
You were noted to be very confused and slurring on ___ night 
and ___ morning. We held your medications briefly and 
decreased your methadone given our concern that your medications 
were interacting. You did not have further episodes of 
confusion.
Your INR (a measure of your coumadin activity) was also very low 
when you arrived, suggesting that there was no protective effect 
of coumadin in your body.  We started you on lovenox to help 
prevent blood clots while the coumadin level builds back up.  
You should continue to take both lovenox and coumadin at home 
and have your INR checked on ___.  Once your INR is 
at a protective level, you can stop taking the lovenox.  This 
will be coordinated by your PCP, ___. 
Please follow up at the appointment listed below.

chronic pain, PE presenting with odynophagia, nausea and 
abdominal pain.

# Odynophagia: Differential included recurrent esophagitis vs 
esophageal or anastamotic ulcer vs infection. Without fevers and 
WBC stable from prior with known history of esophagitis and 
report of lack of adherence to PPI at home, esophagitis was 
thought to be most likely etiology of ___ pain. Her 
esophagitis may also have been worsened by worsened reflux 
related to her constipation as below. Given stable hematocrit 
and no evidence of bleeding on exam, EGD was deferred on this 
admission. Patient was treated with IV PPI BID then transitioned 
to omeprazole BID. Her pain was controlled with home methadone, 
sucralfate and maalox/diphenhydramine/lidocaine mouth wash with 
good effect and patient was able to tolerate POs prior to 
discharge. Patient should continue BID PPI until follow-up with 
GI as an outpatient next month. 

#Abdominal Pain/nausea/vomiting: Patient with significant pain 
to palpation particularly at LLQ with evidence of significant 
stool burden on CT abdomen on admission and no bowel movement 
for 6 days prior to admission. No evidence of infection based on 
CT abdomen, WBC count and temperature (afebrile). Likely that 
___ constipation worsened by methadone and zofran which 
can be constipating. Constipation treated with multiple mineral 
oil and tap water enemas as well as miralax, colace and senna 
with improvement in constipation and abdominal pain. Nausea 
improved with relief of constipation and IV zofran. Patient was 
transitioned back to higher dose of PO zofran prior to discharge 
which she tolerated well. Patient discharged on aggressive bowel 
regimen. Methadone (likely cause of constipation) to be tapered 
per PCP as below.

# Chronic Pain: Per Dr. ___ PCP), patient is 
currently tapering methadone and was scheduled to taper to 5mg 
daily on day of admission. In the setting of symptoms consistent 
with esophagitis, further taper of methadone deferred and 
patient was continued on previous dosing of methadone 5mg BID 
with plan for follow-up at ___ office on ___ for discussion 
regarding further methadone taper. 

# Pinpoint pupils and mild impaired responsiveness: Patient with 
difficulty waking from sleep AM of ___ for ___ minutes. She was 
noted to be difficult to wake fully with pinpoint pupils, 
answering questions but unable to move more than a few inches in 
bed. Spontaneously improved with pupils dilated to baseline. 
Unclear etiology. No known seizure history, no post-ictal state. 
Neurology was curbsided and did not reel that description was 
consistent with any classic seizure presentation. Patient with 
similar issue on last admission and is not sure if this happens 
sometimes at home as well. Other considerations for etiology 
include sleep disorder vs medication effect given multiple 
central acting medications. Patient scheduled for outpatient 
neurology follow-up. Would also consider outpatient sleep study 
if this persists.

reported that they had filled omeprazole for daily dosing. I 
encouraged the patient to continue taking her omeprazole daily 
while awaiting prior auth for bid dosing. Of note, the patient 
often refused her Sucralfate while in the hospital.

___ with PMH significant for morbid obesity s/p gastric 
bypass, multiple GI surgeries including J-tube c/b perforated

and CVA on coumadin who presented with melena and anemia. 

# Upper GI Bleed: Patient presented with melena, anemia, and 
hypotension at her rehab center with SBP in the ___. In the 
___ ED, she received 2 units of PRBCs with appropriate rise in 
her Hb. EGD on ___ showed Grade C esophagitis in the mid and 
distal esophagus compatible with severe esophagitis, as well as 
two outpouchings. She underwent barium swallow that was negative 
for fistula. She was continued on pantoprazole 40mg BID. 
Hemoglobin on day of discharge was 10.8.

# Urinary Tract Infection: Patient with a positive UA, with 
symptoms of dysuria, frequency, and worsening abdominal pain. 
Per ___ records, she has a history of MDR and VRE. She was 
started on ceftriaxone on ___, however, urine cultures 
subsequently grew MDR e.coli. She completed a 5 day course of 
zosyn.

# Leukocytosis: Patient with an increased leukocytosis from 4.8 
to 12.1 while on ceftriaxone for UTI (see above), which could 
represent a stress response given recent EGD and upper GI bleed. 
CXR without pneumonia, blood cultures no growth to date. She was 
treated for UTI as above, with resolution of her leukocytosis. 

# Anticoagulation for history of DVT/PE in ___. Coumadin held 
at rehab given concern for GI bleed. Admission INR of 1.2. Prior 
hematology notes recommended ongoing anticoagulation while the 
patient is immobile, particularly during hospitalizations given 
the extent of her prior VTE.  As she was admitted with UGIB, her 
coumadin continued to be held. As her H/H were subsequently 
stable, the risks and benefits of resuming coumadin. Her 
coumadin was restarted with Lovenox SC as bridging therapy. On 
the day of discharge her INR was 2.1 so her Lovenox was stopped. 
Her INR should be checked daily until her INR stabilizes.

# Acute on Chronic abdominal pain: Patient has a history of 
chronic abdominal pain, and a history of prior narcotic abuse. 
CT A/P was obtained given worsening abdominal pain that was 
negative for acute process. She was continued on her home 
methadone, oxycodone, senna, and sulcrafate. 

CHRONIC ISSUES: 

# History of CVA: Patient has residual left sided weakness. 
Likely not on aspirin given NSAIDS allergy. No record of atrial 
fibrillation of known cause. She reports recrudescence of 
symptoms which occured in the setting of holding warfarin for an 
outpatient spinal surgery. We attempted unsuccessfully to obtain 
OSH records. Given her severe esophagitis, the risks and 
benefits of anticoagulation were discussed with the patient and 
the family, and decision was made to restart anticoagulation 
with warfarin. 
 
# Anxiety/depression:  Continued home medications: seroquel, 
clonazepam, BuPROPion, Doxepin.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year-old female with a history of gastric 
bypass and cholecystectomy with subsequent reversal surgery and 
multiple prior abdominal surgeries including a J-tube in ___ 
with apparent complication of a perforated colon.  She presented 
to ___ on ___ with complaints of abdominal pain and had a 
CT abdomen/pelvis on HD1 which raised concern for intestinal 
perforation.  She was admitted to the Acute Care Surgery team 
and transferred to the Surgical ICU for serial abdominal exams 
and close observation.  
  
On HD2, the patient had a PICC placed for IV access. On HD3, the 
patient underwent a swallow study and a nasogastric tube was 
placed into the stomach by a surgery resident Dr. ___ 
fluoroscopic guidance. Given the patient's history of a past 
DVT, heparin gtt was started and serial PTTs were drawn until 
the patient reached stable therapeutic levels.

After remaining stable in the surgical ICU, the patient was then 
transferred to the step-down surgical floor. 

On HD9, the patient's nasogastric tube was discontinued and she 
was started on a clear liquid diet.  The patient tolerated a 
clear liquid diet and her home medicines were started.

On HD10, the patient was evaluated by the Chronic Pain service 
and her pain medicine regimen was adjusted.  

On HD12 the patient's heparin drip was discontinued and Coumadin 
was initiated. 

Neuro: The patient was alert and oriented throughout 
hospitalization.

CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.

Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. Good pulmonary 
toilet, early ambulation and incentive spirometry were 
encouraged throughout hospitalization. 

GI/GU/FEN: The patient was advanced to a regular diet, which was 
well tolerated. Patient's intake and output were closely 
monitored

ID: The patient's fever curves were closely watched for signs of 
infection.  She had blood cultures drawn on HD1 which grew 
Staphylococcus, coagulase negative.  Nasal swab from HD1 was 
positive for MRSA. H.pylori test from HD2 was shown to be 
equivocal.  

HEME: The patient's blood counts were closely watched for signs 
of bleeding, of which there were none.

Prophylaxis: ___ dyne boots were used during this stay and was 
encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as possible.

At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
and hemodynamically stable.  The patient was tolerating a diet, 
ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well 
controlled. The patient was noted to have an area of rash and 
skin breakdown between her gluteal folds and miconazole powder 
was ordered.  The patient was discharged with mepilex dressings 
and was instructed to alternate positioning to her side to 
relieve pressure.  The patient's left upper extremity PICC was 
removed on ___.  

The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up 
instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with 
the discharge plan.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You presented to the ___ on 
___ with complaints of abdominal pain. You were found to 
have an intestinal perforation. You were admitted to the Acute 
Care Surgery team for further medical treatment. 

Over the course of your hospitalization, you have continued to 
improve.  You are now tolerating a regular diet and your pain is 
controlled with oral pain medication.  You are now ready to be 
discharged to rehab to continue your recovery.  

Please note the following discharge instructions: 

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
Emergency Department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.
*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.
*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.
*Any change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that concern 
you.
Please resume all regular home medications , unless specifically 
advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.
Please get plenty of rest, continue to ambulate several times 
per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.
Avoid driving or operating heavy machinery while taking pain 
medications.

stable vital signs.  The patient's hematocrit was acceptable and 
pain was adequately controlled on an oral regimen. The operative 
extremity was neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign.

Left knee osteoarthritis

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.
 
2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills. 
 
3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.
 
4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.
 
5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon.
 
6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment.
 
7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, 
especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice 
directly on the skin. You may wrap the knee with an ace bandage 
for added compression. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal 
anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex, 
ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc).
 
8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your Couamdin as directed by 
the rehab. Goal INR 2.0-3.0. If you were taking aspirin prior to 
your surgery, it is OK to continue at your previous dose while 
taking this medication.  
 
9. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is 
okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, 
swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) 
week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound 
each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. 
Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or 
thick yellow drainage. 
 
10. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity. Mobilize.  ROM as tolerated. No strenuous exercise or 
heavy lifting until follow up appointment.

Physical Therapy:
ROMAT bilateral knees
WBAT
Mobilize frequently

Treatments Frequency:
DSD daily PRN drainage, okay to leave open to air if no drainage 
on dressing
Wound checks
Ice and elevate

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the orthopedic surgery service 
pre-operatively to be started on a heparin drip.  She was taken 
to the operating room for above described procedure. Please see 
separately dictated operative report for details. The surgery 
was uncomplicated and the patient tolerated the procedure well. 
Patient received perioperative IV antibiotics.

Postoperative course was remarkable for the following:
On POD#1, the patient received 2 units of blood for a hematocrit 
of 28.5.  On POD#2, her hematocrit was 31. 

Otherwise, pain was controlled with a PCA post-operatively.  The 
Chronic Pain service assisted with co-management of the patient. 
 The PCA was discontinued on POD#2 and they assisted with making 
recommendations for oral pain management.  The patient received 
Coumadin and Lovenox for DVT prophylaxis.  The Coumadin was 
resumed on POD#0 and the Lovenox was started on POD#2.  The 
Coumadin was dosed based on her INR levels.  Lovenox was to be 
continued until INR > 2.  The foley was removed and the patient 
was voiding independently thereafter. The surgical dressing was 
changed on POD#2 and the surgical incision was found to be clean 
and intact without erythema or abnormal drainage. The patient 
was seen daily by physical therapy. Labs were checked throughout 
the hospital course and repleted accordingly. At the time of 
discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet and feeling 
well.  The patient was afebrile with stable vital signs.  The 
patient's hematocrit was acceptable and pain was adequately 
controlled on an oral regimen. The operative extremity was 
neurovascularly intact and the wound was benign. 

The patient's weight-bearing status is weight bearing as 
tolerated on the operative extremity.

Discharge Instructions:
1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your 
physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain 
not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased 
sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, 
shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision 
site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns.

2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this 
admission and any new medications and refills. 

3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed.

4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do 
not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while 
taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer 
tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can 
cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily 
and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent 
this side effect.  Call your surgeons office 3 days before you 
are out of medication so that it can be refilled.  These 
medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be 
picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house.  Please allow 
an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your 
home.

5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your 
surgeon.

6. Please call your surgeon's office to schedule or confirm your 
follow-up appointment.

7. SWELLING: Ice the operative joint 20 minutes at a time, 
especially after activity or physical therapy. Do not place ice 
directly on the skin. You may wrap the knee with an ace bandage 
for added compression. Please DO NOT take any non-steroidal 
anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs such as Celebrex, 
ibuprofen, Advil, Aleve, Motrin, naproxen etc).

8. ANTICOAGULATION: Please continue your Coumadin which is being 
dosed based on your INR levels.  You should continue Lovenox 30 
mg twice daily until your INR > 2.  Once your INR > 2, you can 
discontinue the Lovenox and continue Warfarin.  Your INR goal is 
___.  

9. WOUND CARE: Please keep your incision clean and dry. It is 
okay to shower five days after surgery but no tub baths, 
swimming, or submerging your incision until after your four (4) 
week checkup. Please place a dry sterile dressing on the wound 
each day if there is drainage, otherwise leave it open to air. 
Check wound regularly for signs of infection such as redness or 
thick yellow drainage. Staples will be removed at your follow-up 
appointment in three weeks.

10. ___ (once at home): Home ___, dressing changes as 
instructed, wound checks.

11. ACTIVITY: Weight bearing as tolerated on the operative 
extremity. Mobilize.  ROM as tolerated. No strenuous exercise or 
heavy lifting until follow up appointment.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old F with prior CVA with L sided weakness and facial
droop, history of gastric bypass, gastritis, DVT/PE on
anticoagulation, and chronic pain and anxiety on multiple pain
medications who is now admitted due to concern for altered 
mental

sedating meds, but MRI showed new right-sided cerebellar stroke. 


# Altered mental state.  The patient was discharged from her 
previous hospital stay with clear mental status and no acute 
neuro abnormalities.  However, on arrival to her home, she was 
noted to have slurred speech per her family and brought to the 
ER.  She was admitted to medicine where her sedating medications 
were tapered, back to Dilaudid 2mg every 4 hours and 
Promethazine to 6.25 (previously getting 25 last hospital stay). 
 Her mental status was back to normal with this change.  There 
was no evidence of metabolic abnormalities or infection that 
could have been the culprit for her encephalopathy.  I spoke 
with her PCP, ___, who understood the concerns for 
sedating medications, and acknowledged that he shares the goal 
of tapering them further.  We found a bottle of Dilaudid that 
she had from discharge that was empty in the bed.  She could not 
fully explain why the bottle did not have the pills in it that 
were supposed to last 5 days were gone in 2.  We have concerns, 
as does her sister ___, that the patient is not taking her 
medications at home appropriately, forgets doses, and may take 
too many, as she is forgetful.  We suggested that she have 
further assistance at home or elsewhere, but she wanted to 
return to her home.  We will add services such as ___ in addition 
to nursing services that already exist.  

#Acute/Subacute stroke in the right cerebellum.  The patient had

findings.  She was seen by the neurology team who recommended 
that she have a CTA head and neck as well as an echo with bubble 
study.  The strokes were likely embolic in etiology given their 
location, and with Lupus anticoagulant positive (one time), this 
raised suspicion that she may have an underlying thrombophilia 
given her recent strokes in the past.  The patient has been on 
Xarelto for months, and claims to be compliant with this. We 
were unable to determine if she was non-compliant given above 
issues, or if she were compliant, which would represent a 
failure of Xarelto.  If she were to fail Xarelto, she could 
consider Coumadin with INR goal > 2.5.  However, with Hx of 2 GI 
bleeds, this poses risks.  After extensive counseling with the 
patient about the risks and benefits of remaining on Xarelto for 
the interim, she elected to do this, realizing that there is a 
risk of further thrombosis.  She will see a stroke specialist as 
an outpatient as well as a hematologist. She was unable to 
complete CTA secondary to IV infiltration, and inability to 
place another one. She declined a midline and said she would be 
better hydrated as an outpatient and try again.  Echo was done 
the evening prior to discharge, where the results are pending at 
the time of discharge. Her neurologist will use the results to 
help determine next steps in treatment.

ACUTE MEDICAL ISSUES ADDRESSED:
=============================

#Headache
#Nausea/Vomiting
   Patient p/w new progressive headache x 3 weeks, nausea and 
vomiting x 1 day with worsening abdominal pain. CT 
abdomen/pelvis, LFTs and lipase were unremarkable and the n/v 
was suspected to either be a benign viral gastroenteritis, or to 
be related to headache. A new severe headache in a ___ year old 
patient was felt to be concerning for secondary headache.
   The headache was right-sided, radiating from the occiput to 
behind the R eye. Neuro exam unchanged from baseline other than 
a left-sided visual field defect, which is of unclear chonicity; 
otherwise no symptomatic evidence of new stroke. Follow-up 
MRI/MRA was only notable for a questionable punctate infarction 
in the left pons, though imaging artifact was also possible. CRP 
wnl, effectively ruling out temporal arteritis. 
   Pseudotumor cerebri was considered, although fundoscopic exam 
was without papilledema and bedside ultrasound of optic nerve 
also did not suggest increased sheath diameter. LP was planned, 
but aborted at the last minute upon realization that the patient 
had already received lovenox that day. She subsequently improved 
with symptomatic treatment; thus, LP was deferred. The etiology 
remained unclear at discharge and she will follow up in headache 
clinic.

#Abdominal pain
#Chronic pain
#Hx of opiate use disorder
Pt w/ acute on chronic abdominal pain x 1 day, initial exam 
notable for epigastric and LUQ TTP. Lipase, LFTs unremarkable. 
CT abd/pelvis without acute etiology. Believed to be chronic 
baseline pain that worsened in the setting of nausea/vomiting. 
She was continued on methadone, dilaudid, gabapentin, and 
Tylenol with minimal additional dilaudid doses required. Weaned 
back to home regimen by discharge.

#Lethargy
Appeared lethargic on admission but otherwise oriented. She 
reported this was her baseline. There were no clear metabolic 
derangements nor evidence of infectious etiology. Lethargy 
improved some during hospitalization and was overall thought to 
be related to polypharmacy in the setting of methadone, 
dilaudid, gabapentin, and clonazepam. 

#Recurrent CVA on Anticoagulation
Has a history of CVA while on xarelto. On that prior admission, 
neurology had wanted CTA head/neck and TTE w/ bubble, but these 
had not been completed so were belatedly completed on this 
admission. MRA Neck/Head done during this hospitalization was 
overall unremarkable, other than a questionable punctate 
infarction in the left pons, though this had no obvious clinical 
correlate and imaging artifact was also possible. TTE with 
bubble study was done, and it did not show any PFO or ASD. 
Rivaroxaban was briefly switched to lovenox due to nausea and 
poor po intake; however she was switched back to xarelto prior 
to discharge. Of note, her prior positive lupus anticoagulant 
was felt to be a likely false positive, so a repeat was drawn 
while the patient was off anticoagulation as requested by 
Heme/onc, pending at discharge.

ACUTE ISSUES

#CHEST PAIN
Patient presented with several day history of chest pain that 
was worsened on exertion. Noted to be increasing pain with 
inspiration. Could not localize on herself, was not positional 
in nature, and without radiation to arm or neck. She was worked 
up for infectious etiologies which was negative, CTA which ruled 
out PE, EKG which demonstrated no signs of ischemia on 
presentation, transthoracic echocardiogram which demonstrated no 
signs of pericardial fluid concerning for pericarditis, and 
Persantine stress echo which demonstrated no signs of ischemic 
change with stress and normal myocardial perfusion. Of note, her 
transthoracic echocardiogram demonstrated worsening pulmonary 
artery pressure determined to be mild pulmonary hypertension. 
She was determined to be atypical chest pain, likely 
costochondritis, with lidocaine patch to area on chest. NSAIDs 
were not an option due to her underlying allergy. Patient's 
symptoms improved after lidocaine patch therapy and continued to 
subside at discharge.

Her chronic abdominal pain was managed with her home methadone, 
gabapentin, and Dilaudid.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o woman with morbid obesity s/p RYGB (___ II anatomy 
now), CVA, DVT/PE (xarelto), and chronic pain (methadone) 
presenting with shortness of breath and lower extremity edema, 
initially presented to the CDAC. TTE with normal systolic 
function, valvular function, and pulmonary pressures, CXR clear, 
BNP normal. Patient noted to have severe protein-calorie 
malnutrition, likely etiology of her lower extremity edema.  She 
was initially admitted to the cardiology service where she was 
given diuresis, which lead to orthostasis, so Midodrine was 
added.  They initiated tube feeds via NGT and then transferred 
her to the hospitalist service on the ___. 

=================
ACTIVE ISSUES
=================
# Severe protein-calorie malnutrition c/b peripheral edema: 
Patient noted to have severe malnutrition in setting of prior 
gastric bypass. GI recommended that the patient take small, 
frequent meals. The cardiology team, along with Nutrition 
decided to place an NGT tube, and the patient was initiated on 
tube feeds. In discussion with this team, there was no planned 
end-point in this therapy.  I discussed with her primary 
outpatient GI MD. ___ stated that her weight fluxuates, and that 
the TFs are unnecessary.  In addition, she experienced nausea, 
bloating, and some abdominal pain with these.  The NG tube was 
removed, and her symptoms improved.  She was able to eat 
sufficient meals and was pleased with her progress.  She will 
follow-up with Gastroenterology as well as nutrition as an 
outpatient. All of her home medications were kept the same as 
they were on admission.  

___ edema - the patient had SaO2 of ___ in clinic; however, when 
she was admitted to the floor, ambulatory SaO2 was 94-95% on RA 
per the report of the medical resident.  The Cardiology team 
treated her empirically for diastolic heart failure with 
Torsemide, which caused diuresis but also orthostasis.  
Torsemide was stopped, and we instituted TEDS as well as 
lymphedema wraps.  Wee discussed that mechanical (wraps), and 
not medical therapy would be best ___ for symptoms of this 
nature.  I also explained that dizziness or orthostasis should 
be dealt with by having slower movements with position changes.  
Midodrine was added but caused nausea symptoms, so this was not 
advised to continue and also to reduce polypharmacy.  

# AVNRT: Patient had single episode of AVNRT that 
self-terminated and has not recurred. Question whether her 
presenting symptom of shortness of breath was perhaps an 
arrhythmia, but no further events occurred on telemetry, and she 
experienced this symptom without any arrhythmia on the monitor.  
There is no need for further monitoring at this time.  

# DVT/PE: Patient previously on warfarin but switched to 
rivaroxaban, possibly at a prior rehab stay this year. Patient 
did have a stroke while on rivaroxaban. Given her gastric bypass 
and limited ability to eat a 500-calorie meal, rivaroxaban may 
be poorly absorbed and therefore less effective; however, her 
home compliance with meds is also in question which may have led 
to failure. She was able to take enough food to have AC to be 
effective.  There is no need to consider switching back to 
warfarin for anticoagulation at this time.

and lying; ___ will continue dressing changes.

her po intake. Uptitrated gabapentin and uptitrated duloxetine

# DVT/PE: 
Patient previously on warfarin but switched to rivaroxaban,

absorption in patients with gastric bypass and it is difficult

adequate absorption in gastric bypass patients, and she has been

given her improvement with a nine day course of ceftazadime, she 
should be sufficiently treated for a pseudomonal pneumonia. She

# Acute on Chronic abdominal pain:
# nausea:
Pt has chronic ___ mid abd pain at baseline, with ___ 
RUQ/epigastric abd pain on admission. Reassuringly, chemistries, 
LFTs and CBC are wnl, Lactate:1.3 and trop X 1 undetectable. CT 
A&P also showed no acute intra-abdominal process to explain the 
patient's symptoms. In fact, there is little to no residual 
fluid component of a left RP collection, measuring 1.7 x 1.0 cm, 
(likely representing evolving hematoma) and the left iliacus 
collection is no longer visualized. There was mild intrahepatic 
biliary ductal dilatation and dilation of the CBD (unchanged 
from prior), however she is s/p cholecystectomy and LFTs without 
any abnormalities. Multi-factoral pain possible from prior 
gastritis, secondary gastroparesis from prior abdominal 
surgeries, narcotic bowel syndrome, and distorted GI anatomy. 
Viral gastroenteritis less likely etiology of abd pain and 
nausea. Functional abdominal pain is also possible, but dx of 
exclusion and timing is atypical. Most likely dx is exacerbation 
of prior gastritis given location, prior hx of gastritis given 
EGD findings, and relationship to eating/taking pills with 
almost instantaneous precipitation. She was thus escalated to PO 
BID PPI in addition to initiation of sucralfate. Maintained on 
promethazine for nausea given Compazine allergy. She was 
maintained on standing bowel regimen. Over few days this 
combination provided relief from instant pain/nausea following 
consumption and ultimately allowed successful advancement of 
diet. Remained on Methadone 10 TID per PCP, ___, and 
daily EKGs for QTc monitoring.

# Seizure disorder
She experienced generalized body shaking on ___ concerning for 
generalized tonic clonic seizure. She received IV Ativan 1mg x3 
for what appeared to be at least 2 separate episodes 
approximately 10 minutes apart. Etiology may be medication 
related, infectious from UTI though
less likely, subtherapeutic on AEDs given questionable adherence
at home per family, poor diet. Toxic metabolic and ischemic 
causes were less likely to be the culprit. Also noted to use 
eCigarettes per family, which can also be seizurogenic. Her 
ciprofloxacin was discontinued as this can lower seizure 
threshold. Neurology was consulted and EEG was placed to monitor 
for seizure activity. She did not have any further seizures and 
was only noted to have bursts of theta slowing, which are 
nonspecific, and will always be present on her EEG per 
neurology. Her wellbutrin was held on admission and was 
discontinued on discharge as this can also lower the seizure 
threshold. Her lacosamide and keppra levels were drawn and 
pending at the time of discharge.

Brief Hospital Course: 
Ms. ___ is a ___ yo woman with history of stroke, baseline L 
arm/leg weakness, and NCSE who presented with acute onset speech 
change, left facial as well as left upper/lower extremity 
weakness and headache. Exam on admission with mildly decreased 
fluency aphasia with paraphasic errors, L facial droop with 
+labial dysarthria, and left hemiparesis in UMN pattern. This is 
one of at least three identical presentations in the past year. 
MRI without co-localizing stroke in the other two admissions 
(during ___ admission, there were three punctate cerebellar 
infarcts, felt to be incidental and unrelated). These 
presentations are all accompanied by throbbing R-sided headache. 
MRI brain did not reveal new lesions. Initial workup positive 
for hypoglycemia and a UTI. Pt started on antibiotic for UTI, 
hypoglycemia corrected and headache was treated with migraine 
cocktail. With these interventions strength and fluency of 
speech returned to baseline and dysarthria resolved.

Brief Hospital Course:
SUMMARY:
====================  
___ is a ___ y.o. F with a PMHx notable for gastric 
bypass (c/b SBO), esophagitis/gastritis, PUD/HCV, 
cholecystectomy, nephrolithiasis, and CVA (___) who presented 
to ___ on ___ with a week of nausea, abdominal discomfort, 
and vomiting x2 days. Of note, she had been previously evaluated 
by GI in ___ for the same presenting symptoms.

ACTIVE ISSUES:  
====================  
# Abdominal Pain
# Gastritis
# Esophagitis
The patient presented with weakness and lethargy in the setting 
of nausea and vomiting with poor PO intake. Of note, EGD ___: 
c/w esophagitis, gastritis. She was recently seen by GI in 
___ as a consult while admitted for identical symptoms. 
Recommendations at that time were to treat supportively with PPI 
BID and anti-emetics. Given her history of SBO, a CT A/P was 
performed on ___ which demonstrated no bowel obstruction. Of 
note despite recommendations to be discharged on BID PPI, her 
daughter endorses that she has only been taking omeprazole 20mg 
once daily at home (unclear how discrepancy arose). We treated 
her supportively with increased dose of PPI 40mg BID, 
sucralfate, and anti-emetics. She remained afebrile, without 
diarrhea for the entire hospital stay and decreased frequency of 
nausea.

#Prolonged QTc Interval:
#Chronic Pain requiring methadone:
Patient on home regimen of Methadone 10mg TID. Her QTc on 
arrival to the ED ___ was 412. She received Zofran to treat her 
nausea. Repeat EKG on ___ was 527. A trial of Ativan was used to 
treat her nausea which was effective, but there was concern of 
continued use given her concurrent use of other sedating 
medications and a significant episode of transient confusion. 
After trialing Zofran again for her nausea her QTc returned to 
525. No further anti-emetics with QTc prolong effects were 
given. QTc on day of discharge was 420. We attempted to wean 
methadone while inpatient however patient was unwilling to do so 
therefore she was discharged on prior regimen.

#Hypomagnesemia:
Patient admitted with Mg2+ of 1.4. Her magnesium remained low 
despite multiple attempts at IV repletion. She ranged from 
1.4-1.9 during her admission. This was of significant concern 
given the above issue of her prolonged QTc interval. She was 
discharged on Magnesium Oxide 400 mg PO BID. Mg2+ on discharge 
was 1.9.

#Hypoglycemia 
During the early part of the admission, patient had glucose 
levels from 49 - 74. This is likely due to minimal PO intake in 
the setting of abdominal discomfort and nausea. As her nausea 
improved and she was able tolerate po intake, nutrition was 
consulted and recommended additional supplementation with 
carnation instant breakfast at each meal. TSH and AM cortisol 
unremarkable. Her morning glucose on day of discharge was 87. If 
she is persistently having issues with hypoglycemia in the 
future would consider endocrine referral.

#Altered mental status
The patient had an episode of confusion and short term memory 
loss on morning of ___. She was awake, alert, and interactive. 
However, she was AOx1. Additionally, throughout her admission, 
the patient had intermittent episodes of drowsiness and 
lethargy. We spoke to her daughter who says these episodes have 
occurred almost every day since she suffered her CVA. Given that 
this is a long-standing issue we planned for continued follow-up 
with neurology as an outpatient. This may be the presentation of 
subclinical seizure activity, but there is also concern for 
polypharmacy. She was awake, alert, interactive, and AOx3 on 
discharge. 

#Severe Hypoalbuminemia:
#Malnutrition:
Significant weight loss, nearly 20lbs. Poor PO intake secondary 
to abdominal pain. Albumin as low as 1.8. Seen by nutrition. 
Started on carnation supplementation and increased her zinc 
dose. Maintained on thiamine and folic acid. 

#Gait instability:
___ evaluation reveals: Impairments of Body Functions and 
Structures, Activity Limitations and Participation Restrictions 
- Knowledge deficit RE: fall risk
- Impaired cognition
- Impaired functional mobility 
- Impaired balance
- Impaired strength

# Altered mental status 
# Word finding difficulty
Patient sent from rehab with report of "appearing more confused, 
repeated words and statement multiple times, agitated," 
increasing word finding difficulty, with extra pauses in 
sentences. Initial concern was for CVA vs seizure. CT head 
without contrast was not concerning for stroke. Patient had 
outpatient EEG earlier that week which was reassuring. She was 
evaluated by Neurology who felt she was at baseline and 
recommended against further imaging (MRI, EEG). Patient seemed 
to be mentating appropriately throughout her hospitalization. 
She was ultimately treated for a UTI but this was felt unlikely 
to cause her AMS. Infectious and metabolic workup was otherwise 
unrevealing (TSH, B12 WNL, RPR nonreactive, blood cultures NGTD, 
no leukocytosis). Doxepin and Seroquel were held due to concern 
for medication effect / prolonged QTc, patient was reported to 
be very sleepy at rehab. Doxepin was restarted at discharge, 
Seroquel was held (though patient reported she had not been 
receiving Seroquel at rehab to begin with). Methadone was also 
held but restarted. Patient received 2 doses of high-dose IV 
Thiamine, though ultimately Wernicke's was felt to be unlikely. 

# Dizziness
Patient reported feeling dizzy upon standing for the past 3 days 
prior to admission, coinciding with starting Lasix for lower 
extremity edema, which was stopped on admission. Patient 
continued to report some dizziness with standing. Orthostatic 
vital signs were not positive but patient did not tolerate 
standing due to dizziness. She was evaluated by ___ who suspected 
some mild orthostasis (rather than vertigo) and recommended 
continuing to work on this at rehab. Neurology was not concerned 
for BPPV. Compression stockings were placed and encouraged PO 
intake.

# UTI
Positive UA in ED, which appeared consistent with her priors. 
Received 1 dose of IV ceftriaxone for UTI, then denied dysuria 
so antibiotics were stopped as she was thought to be colonized. 
Then she reported adamantly that she did have dysuria. Urine 
culture was contaminated, but patient was started on 5d course 
of macrobid for empiric treatment of uncomplicated UTI, to be 
completed ___.

Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER ORTHOPAEDIC SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for orthopedic surgery. It is normal 
to feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
-Nonweightbearing to the right upper extremity in a splint

MEDICATIONS:
- Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians 
at discharge.
- Continue all home medications unless specifically instructed 
to stop by your surgeon.
- Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
- Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you should 
drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and take a stool softener 
(colace) to prevent this side effect.

ANTICOAGULATION:
- Please take aspirin 325 mg daily for 4 weeks

WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Please remain in your dressing and do not change unless it is 
visibly soaked or falling off.
- Splint must be left on until follow up appointment unless 
otherwise instructed
- Do NOT get splint wet

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever > 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

THIS PATIENT IS EXPECTED TO REQUIRE <30 DAYS OF REHAB

FOLLOW UP:
Please follow up with your Orthopaedic Surgeon, Dr. ___. 
You will have follow up with ___, NP in the 
Orthopaedic Trauma Clinic ___ days post-operation for 
evaluation. Call ___ to schedule appointment upon 
discharge.

Please follow up with your primary care doctor regarding this 
admission within ___ weeks and for and any new 
medications/refills.

Physical Therapy:
Nonweightbearing to the right upper extremity in a splint
Treatments Frequency:
Remain in the splint until your follow-up appointment.  The 
staples/sutures will remain for at least 2 weeks 
postoperatively.  Please keep the splint dry.  If you have 
concerns regarding the splint, please call the clinic at the 
number provided.

Chest pain, dyspnea: 

The patient was admitted to the floor hypertensive (180/82) but 
otherwise in stable condition without chest pressure or dyspnea 
(T=98.2, BP=180/82, HR=83, RR=18, O2 sat=100% on RA). EKG in the 
ED showed no ischemic changes, and 3 sets of cardiac enzymes 
were normal, making acute coronary syndrome unlikely.  Urine tox 
was negative for cocaine use, also ruling out a syndrome X, or 
acute narrowing of the coronary arteries.  Given the patient's 
lack of compliance with her HTN and GERD medications, her 
episode likely reflected a hypertensive crisis with possible 
overlying reflux.  Her emphysema may have also contributed to 
her SOB.  

The patient received a prednisone taper 60 mg, ___, as well 
as albuterol prn, ipratropium nebs, and fluticasone-salmeterol 
for her emphysema and experienced improvements in her breathing. 
 She was restarted on her home nifedipine and was half her home 
valsartan dose, which subsequently normalized her blood 
pressures.  She was also started on her home aspirin 81 mg daily 
and ompeprazole.  A lipid panel was drawn, which was within 
normal limits, including a LDL of 111.  Giver a ___ risk 
score of 4%, a statin was not initiated.  At the time of 
discharge, the patient had been free of chest pressure and SOB 
for 48 hours. 

Urinary retention with baseline ___ weakness/numbness/tingling: 

Despite recent initiation of opiods for pain control in the ED 
and on the floor, the patient's new onset of urinary retention 
upon reaching the floor raised concern for cord compression.  L 
spine MR was performed showing no evidence for cord compression, 
spinal stenosis or foramenal narrowing.  The patient's urinary 
retention resolved that evening and recurred the next day with 
constipation following her morning morphine dose.  Opiods were 
discontinued.  With a bowel regimen, the constipation and 
urinary retention resolved, and the patient was discharged on 
tylenol for pain control. 

Given the patient's complaints of of baseline L leg weakness and 
b/l ___ numbness and tingling, B12, TSH, folate levels were drawn 
rule out possible metabolic sources of of peripheral neuropathy. 
 An outpatient Neurology appointment was arranged to follow up 
likely peripheral neuropathy underlying these symptoms.  

A ___ consult was called and cleared the patient for ambulation 
at home, though visiting home services were arranged for the 
patient's chronic pain and anxiety.

HTN: 

The pt was acutely hypertensive on admission (SBP 180-190), and 
resolved on home nifedipine and ___ dose of valsartan with which 
she was discharged.

RUQ pain / bruising: 

Likely related to patient's hepatitis, the patient's LFTs were 
mildly elevated and coag studies wnl.  There were no acute 
issues during her hospital stay.

PVD: 

No issues. A recent Cardiology appointment judged the patient's 
lower extremity symptoms to be unlikely due to her PVD given ABI 
showing minimal disease below the knees.  As discussed above, 
her ___ weakness, numbness and tingling is ossibly due to 
peripheral neuropathy secondary to alcohol abuse. Outpatient 
neurology appointment was scheduled. 

Alcohol abuse:

Given the patient's history of alcohol abuse, she was placed on 
CIWA protocol but showed no signs of withdrawal throughout her 
stay.

Fibromyalgia:

The patient was given Morphine 15 mg po q12h for pain control 
and then transitioned to tylenol given the patient's new onset 
of urinary retention and constipation. Home visiting services 
were arranged to help the patient cope with the patient's 
chronic pain and anxiety.

hospital, an electrocardiogram and lab tests showed that you did

nifedipine and half dose of valsartan for your blood pressure

started to help prevent future heart attack.  For your shortness

.

for further management of your lower extremity symptoms, which 
may be due to peripheral neuropathy.

After receiving steroids, nebs and azithromycin in the ED, she states that her symptoms substantially improved. Pt has had no fevers, leukocytosis, or x-ray findings of consolidation, thus PNA is highly unlikely. Pt has been ruled out for MI w/ two negative EKGs and troponin markers. Smoking cessation counseling was provided but patient states she is not ready to quit and that she has already significantly cut down her smoking from 3 packs to about half a pack per day. We advise pt to use air filter at home and keep windows closed to limit environmental allergens. We continue home spiriva inhaler and was able to arrange for patient to get a home nebulizer unit for at home albuterol nebulizer treatments which the patient felt worked better than the MDI. On discharge patient was still short of breath given her severe COPD but her breathing was back at baseline. # RUE pain and weakness: Pt presented with pain and weakness in her right arm and hand which she states has been present for a long time although it was now more painful. Pt does have chronic tremor and chronic R sided pain/weakness, which may be from cervical spinal dysfunction or peripheral nervous issues. #Dyspnea: Patient presented with a 3 week history of worsening 
shortness of breath which was likely multifactorial due to

well as increased abdominal distension from new large volume 
ascites. There was no evidence of heart failure, pneumonia, or 
hepatic hydrothorax on EKG and chest xray. Home Advair and 
Spiriva were restarted, and patient underwent therapeutic 
paracentesis yielding 1,200cc with improvement in respiratory 
function. No longer requiring supplemental O2 during the day, 
was able to walk 100+ ft with SpO2>94% on RA.   

#New large volume ascites: Likely due to the progression of 
liver disease to cirrhosis ___ to EtOH use in the setting of HCV 
infection and liver fribrosis. Serum Albumin Ascites Gradient 
(SAAG) was 1.7, suggestive of portal HTN, Budd-Chiari syndrome, 
or CHF. The was no evidence of CHF on EKG or CXR. RUQ U/S showed 
liver cirrhosis but no portal venous thrombosis. Diagnostic 
paracentesis performed in ED was negative for SBP. Ascites fluid 
cultures did not grow anything. A therapeutic paracentesis was 
performed as an inpatient yielding 1200cc with improvement in 
the patient's abdominal discomfort as well respiratory function. 
Patient started on spiranolactone 25mg PO daily and lasix 20mg 
PO daily. Patient was educated by nutrition specialist on how to 
maintain low sodium diet. Due to continued abdominal pain, KUB 
was obtained which was negative for free air. Patient was then 
sent for ___ guided tap but only a small volume of ascites was 
found which was insufficient for therapeutic paracentesis. 
Patient discharged with ultram for pain control. Appointment was 
made for patient to follow-up with Dr. ___ on ___ 
___, at which time she will have her serum electolytes 
checked again (K increased from 4.1 to 4.4 after 2 days on 
lasix/aldactone). An appointment was also made for patient to 
follow-up with hepatology as an outpatient. 

#Transaminitis: Patient presented with an elevated AST(245) and 
ALT(89). AST/ALT ratio >2:1, suggestive of alcoholic hepatitis, 
which is consistent with her drinking history. Alk phos was also 
elevated at 233. Tbili was normal at 1.1. ___ DF on 
admission was 11. AST, ALT, and Alk Phos trended down slightly 
during her stay. Tbili remained normal throughout her stay. 
Patient was counseled about the importance of stopping alcohol 
as well as cocaine use.

#Alcoholic/HCV cirrhosis: ___ liver biospy showed stage ___ 
fibrosis, however ascites on exam suggests cirrhosis. CT abd/pel 
w/o contrast showed new ascites, no acute liver changes. RUQ 
ultrasound showed cirrhosis of the liver but no PVT. Given 
patient's known HCV and heavy ETOH use, the progression to 
cirrhosis is not surprising. MELD score 11. Repeat EGD

evidence of esophageal varices. Nodularity and erythema in the

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

It was pleasure taking care of you during your hospital stay at 
___. As you know, you were 
admitted to the hospital because you were having abdominal 
discomfort and shortness of breath. We performed blood tests 
which showed that your liver was injured, likely as a result of 
you drinking alcohol on top of having Hepatitis C.

An ultrasound showed that your liver has become scarred, which 
can represent a condition known as cirrhosis. 

Because of your liver not working well, fluid accumulated in 
your belly and made you feel uncomfortable. We removed some of 
the fluid from your belly to alleviate your belly pain. We also 
tested the fluid to make sure it was not infected and it was 
not. People who have cirrhosis sometimes develop varices 
(distended veins) in their esophagus which can bleed 
significantly. We performed an upper endoscopy and did not see 
any varices in you. In order to prevent even more damage to your 
liver, it is very important that you stop drinking alcohol and 
stop using cocaine.

In order to decrease the chance of fluid reaccumulating in your 
belly, we started you on two new medications (lasix and 
aldactone). You will need to go on a low salt diet as was 
explained to you by the dietician. 

We have made an appointment for you to follow-up with Dr. ___ 
___ ___. We have also made an 
appointment for you to see a liver doctor (___) on 
___ for further management of your likely liver 
cirrhosis and hepatitis C.
 
The shortness of breath you were experiencing when you came into 
the hospital was probably due to a combination of the belly 
fluid as well as you not being able to take the inhalers for 
your COPD. After we removed some of the belly fluid and gave you 
your inhalers, your breathing improved. It is important that you 
follow-up with your primary care doctor to ensure that you 
maintain a constant supply of your medications.

continue to take your inhalers as prescribed. 

Please call your physician if you notice more blood in your 
stools and come to the emergency room if you experience acute 
worsening of shortness of breath or dizziness.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital with abdominal pain.  There 
were likely multiple causes for this, including ascites (fluid), 
and you improved somewhat after we drained out this fluid.

You were confused and had hand shaking (asterixis), which is a 
marker of a condition called hepatic encephalopathy. We started 
you medications called Lactulose and Rifaximin to treat this 
condition.

Because a kidney injury developed, we decreased the dose of your 
water pill (Lasix, aka Furosemide).  The dose is now 20mg, it 
used to be 40mg.  We also stopped your Nadolol, Amlodipine, and 
Gabapentin.

It was a privilege to care for you in the hospital, and we wish 
you all the best.

Dear Ms ___,

Why was I admitted to the hospital?

What was done for me in the hospital?

appointment below.

make your liver disease worse, and can ultimately lead to death. 

 
When should I return to the hospital?

blood in your vomit or in your stool, if you pass out, or any 
other symptoms that concern you.

ACTIVE ISSUES: 

# Abdominal distension 
# Abdominal pain 
Patient presented with abdominal distension and pain, due to 
large ascites, with paracentesis negative for SBP. Paracentesis 
on admission removed 6.1L fluid. She continued to have baseline 
chronic abdominal pain this admission. Her home diuretic regimen 
was uptitrated, from Lasix 20 to 40 daily. She was trialed on 
spironolactone, but became hyperkalemic as below, so 
spironolactone was discontinued. She received multiple 
paracenteses over the course of admission, with the most recent 
on ___ with removal of 2.5 L of fluid (no albumin was given 
after). An order was placed in OMR to have weekly outpatient 
therapeutic paracenteses. 

# Hyperkalemia, improved
Patient became hyperkalemic this admission to peak K 5.7. This 
was likely due to spironolactone effect; K was WNL prior to 
initiation of spironolactone. She did not have EKG changes. She 
received her PO Lasix and no other temporizing measures, and K 
on day of discharge ___ was 5.2. Would be hesitant to give 
her spironolactone in the future, as she was very sensitive to 
hyperkalemic medication effect. 

# Acute on chronic anemia 
Patient with acute on chronic anemia, hgb dropping from 8.4 to 
5.5, with transient hypotension after her paracentesis. There 
was concern for bleed, but CT A/P was negative. She was 
transfused 2U pRBC with hgb bumping to 9.4. Hemolysis labs were 
not convincing for hemolysis being the primary cause of her 
anemia. Given her stability, and lack of active bleeding with 
negative stool guaiac x1, inpatient EGD was deferred. She will 
need outpatient EGD scheduled. 

CHRONIC ISSUES:

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___, 

It was a pleasure caring for you at ___ 
___. 

WHY WERE YOU ADMITTED? 
- Your abdomen was very distended with fluid.

WHAT HAPPENED IN THE HOSPITAL? 
- You received paracentesis procedures to drain the large amount 
of fluid that had built up in your abdomen. 
- You had a brief episode of low blood pressure, and your blood 
counts dropped, so we were worried about bleeding. You were 
given 2 blood transfusions. In the end, it did not look like you 
had any active bleeding, and you were stable. 
- Your home diuretic medications ("water pills") were adjusted 
and increased, to help prevent you from reaccumulating fluid so 
fast. 
- Your potassium became elevated, which was likely because of a 
medication effect. Your potassium returned to more normal levels 
by discharge. 

WHAT SHOULD YOU DO ON DISCHARGE? 
- Please follow up with your primary care doctor and liver 
doctor as scheduled.
- An order was placed for you to have weekly paracenteses to 
drain the fluid from your abdomen.  The radiology department 
will call you to schedule a date and time but tentatively for 
next week ___.  
- Please take your medications as instructed. 
- Please be sure to eat well, and to eat a low salt diet.
- Please stay sober from drugs and alcohol and cigarettes.  If 
you are sober, you may be a candidate for a liver transplant. 

We wish you the best, 
Your ___ team

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ year-old lady with HCV/EtOH cirrhosis 
who presented with abdominal pain after elective paracentesis, 
developed transient urinary retention, and continued to have 
chronic pain.

# Decompensated HCV/EtOH Cirrhosis
# Hepatic encephalopathy
Known history of grade 1 varices, ascites and hepatic 
encephalopathy. No h/o SBP or GIB. Sent from Liver clinic to ED 
after c/o abdominal pain 1 week after therapeutic paracentesis. 
Mild asterixis and volume overload noted. Flu negative. Reported 
last alcohol 1 month ago. Liver U/S with patent vasculature. 
Diagnostic bedside paracentesis performed, negative for SBP. 
Continued on rifaximin, lactulose. Therapeutic paracentesis 
performed with 3L removed. Given albumin 25g x1, then 50g x2. 
Attempted repeat paracentesis, but insufficient fluid to 
successfully drain. Held home furosemide/spironolactone.

# Abdominal Pain
# Chronic Pain
# Polysubstance misuse disorder
History of chronic pain. On tramadol, pregabalin, and APAP at 
home. Last underwent paracentesis ___ and complained of 
abdominal pain afterwards. Multiple similar admission. Over the 
course of the admission, with further discussion it seems the 
pain is severe, but longstanding. Notes "bone pain" throughout, 
R hip locking, mandible pain, and abdominal pain. Also notes 
pain/odd sensation with urination and defection which she 
reports has been present since before the admission. Consulted 
dental and obtained panorex which showed no infection. Consulted 
chronic pain and trialed cyclobenzaprine and baclofen, however 
both were discontinued due to urinary retention. Continued on 
tramadol, tylenol, pregabalin, and lidocaine patch. At time of 
discharge, pain at baseline from prior to admission.

# Urinary Retention
Noted new inability to urinate with high bladder scans. Foley 
catheter placed after several straight cath attempts. Also 
complained of new fecal incontinence to RN and thigh numbness. 
Sensation intact on exam and rectal tone present, but obtained 
MRI spine which showed no signs of cord compression. Stopped 
cyclobenzaprine, Dilaudid, loratidine, baclofen. Urology 
consulted and recommended home w/ foley for ___ days, but then 
she briefly was able to void on her own. Retention presumed ___ 
med effect from cyclobenzaprine and/or baclofen but also may be 
a component of neurogenic bladder given neuropathy elsewhere. 
Repeat retention on day of discharge. ___ placed to remain in 
with urology follow-up.

# Acute Kidney Injury
Baseline Cr 0.7-0.8. Admission Cr 1.1 likely representing 
significant decrease in GFR due to patient's size and lack of 
muscle mass. No hyponatremia or hydronephrosis. Cr peaked at 
1.4, then improved s/p 2 day of 1mg/kg albumin. Held home 
furosemide.

# T2 Hyperintense Signal
9mm segment of T2 hyperintensity noted in the central cord at 
the T1 level on Thoracic MRI, not seen on previous exams and not 
confirmed on axial sequences. Could be syringohydromyelia or 
prominent central canal; unclear clinical significance. No 
notable dermatomal sensory or strength deficits. Deferred 
further evaluation, which could be done with a contrast-enhanced 
MRI.

Brief Hospital Course:
Summary 
=========
Ms. ___ is a ___ female with HCV (genotype 1a) and 
EtOH cirrhosis (child's class B) c/b ascites, esophageal 
varices, and hepatic encephalopathy, hx polysubstance abuse, 
COPD, HTN, and HLD who presented with abdominal pain and FTT, 
s/p large volume paracentesis with no evidence of SBP, s/p EGD 
showing grade II esophageal varices and portal hypertensive 
gastropathy, s/p NJ tube placement, who was started on tube 
feeds prior to discharge. 

#Abdominal pain - Presented with acute on chronic abdominal 
pain. S/p large volume paracentesis no e/o SBP. Likely ___ 
ascites, also with midline hernias, reducible no evidence of 
strangulation or incarceration. CT A/P showing increase in size 
of umbilical hernia no e/o obstruction, also with 11mm left 
adnexal mass. S/p EGD showing grade II esophageal varices and 
changes c/w portal hypertensive gastropathy. She improved 
symptomatically with therapeutic paracentesis. 

#HCV/alcohol cirrhosis (Child's C) - 
#Acute hepatic encephalopathy
Pt presented with acute alteration in MS and falls, thought to 
be a combination of recent initiation of tizanidine and 
worsening hepatic encephalopathy. She cleared with cessation of 
offending medications and multiple bowel movements. She was 
continued on rifaximin and lactulose for control. During her 
stay she underwent EGD which showed Grade II esophageal varices 
with some portal hypertensive gastropathy. She had x2 LVP's, 
most recently on ___. She continued on her epclusa for HCV 
treatment, and she was started on NJ feeds for protein-calorie 
malnutrition. 

#L adenexal mass - Found to have 11mm left adenexal mass. 
Appears stable compared to prior to imaging, however with 
elevated CA-125. GYN saw the patient in house who recommended 
f/u in 4 weeks with repeated serum evaluation. Her peritoneal 
fluid cytology was pending at the time of discharge. 

___ 
Baseline Cr 0.8-1.1, elevated to 1.4 on admission. Diuretics had 
been previously held on discharge on ___ given recurrence ___ 
iso diuresis and poor PO intake. Improved with holding diuretics 
and albumin infusion. Diuretics resumed prior to d/c with cycled 
TF's. 

#Ankle/back pain 
#Myofacial pain
Pt tolerated APAP only during admission for pain, additional 
medications were held given initial AMS. 

#COPD 
- continue home fluticasone-salmeterol diskus
- Continue tiotropium
- Continue albuterol PRN 

#GERD
- Continue pantoprazole 40mg daily 

#HLD
- Continue simvastatin 20mg 

#HTN
- hold valsartan, amlodipine

Transitional issues:
[] Pt will be getting cycled tube feeds overnight for her 
protein-calorie malnutrition
[] Cont with weekly large volume paracenteses for volume 
management
[] Pt will restart her lasix in an effort to prevent need for 
more frequent paracenteses
[] Pt should be considered for palliative care referral in the 
outpatient setting
[] Pt needs f/u with GYN as scheduled for adnexal mass and 
elevated tumor markers

Brief Hospital Course:
___ PMH HCV (genotype 1a)/EtOH cirrhosis (c/b ascites, 
esophageal varices, and hepatic encephalopathy), polysubstance 
use disorder, HLD, COPD, PVD, GERD s/p lap fundoplication and 
hiatal hernia repair, presenting with fall likely due to 
overmedication or hepatic encephalopathy iso not taking 
sufficient lactulose, course c/b hyponatremia and anemia. 

# Hyponatremia: Likely due to free water intake and poor solute 
intake in the setting of cirrhosis, less likely HRS. Improved 
with albumin, IV Lasix, and starting 2L fluid restriction. Na on 
discharge 132.

# Normocytic Anemia: Baseline Hb ___, Hb of 6.8 on ___ likely 
due to fluid shifts rather than acute GIB. No melena per 
RN/patient report. EGD ___ showed grade II varices in the distal 
esophagus. Patient received 1U pRBC on ___ with appropriate 
response.

# Abdominal Pain: Likely chronic due to cirrhosis and volume 
overload. No evidence of infection on initial diagnostic 
paracentesis. No e/o clot on RUQUS ___. S/p therapeutic 
paracentesis ___ and ___ (1.4L). Patient received pregabalin 
150 mg BID and morphine 10 mg Q4H:PRN max total daily dose of 40 
mg for pain, and methadone 2.5 mg daily was started on this 
admission per palliative care recommendations.

# Hepatic Encephalopathy: Patient confused with positive 
asterixis on admission exam concerning for HE. Mental status 
improved w/ lactulose. Pt reports she was not taking lactulose 
regularly at home. Infectious studies negative to date. Patient 
received lactulose to target ___ BM/day and rifaxamin 550 mg BID 
and mental status improved to baseline.

# Transaminitis: Patient with new transaminitis on admission. 
Likely due to mild rhabdomyolysis given elevated CK on admission 
vs. patient taking statin at home which was supposed to be held. 
Transaminitis downtrended prior to discharge. Statin was removed 
from medication list. 

# T2DM: Pt with new hyperglycemia in setting of starting TF. 
___ was consulted. Patient was discarged on 8U lantus QAM, 
Humalog sliding scale, and 22U NPH prior to starting TF in the 
evening. Patient received education on how to use insulin and 
check her sugars. Requires close follow up with ___.

# PAD: ___ pain worse with walking concerning for claudication. 
___ pulses intact on exam. ABI ___ shows severe b/l disease with 
e/o critical limb ischemia on the right, worse compared to 
prior. Vascular surgery recommended outpatient follow up.

# Oral candidiasis: Patient received nystatin swish and swallow 
(___) with improvement in symptoms and resolution of oral 
thrush. Nystatin discontinued at discharge.

# Troponemia. Patient w/ elevated troponin and CK-MB on 
admission, however in the absence of EKG changes or chest pain 
heparin was deferred. TTE without evidence of wall motion 
abnormalities. Patient without chest pain throughout admission 
but did note chest pressure during hospitalization. Troponin 
down trended to normal and repeat EKG shows no changes compared 
to prior.

# Fall: Patient presented with fall without LOC and presyncope. 
Likely due to medication effect (taking tizanidine which was 
supposed to be on hold and not spacing morphine/pregabalin) and 
hepatic encephalopathy iso not taking home lactulose. Palliative 
care had home medications brought in and inappropriate 
medications were disposed.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o woman with a history of HCV and alcoholic cirrhosis c/b 
ascites requiring weekly paracentesis, esophageal/rectal 
varices, and hepatic encephalopathy who presented with subacute 
rib fractures and diffuse abdominal pain, hospital course c/b 
odynophagia, anemia, and concern for adrenal insufficiency 

ACUTE ISSUES:
=============
#Acute on Chronic Abdominal Pain
The patient has an extensive history of intermittent, diffuse 
abdominal pain though particularly worse over her multiple 
umbilical hernias. Her pain has previously had minimal 
improvement following large volume paracentesis.  She presented 
with acute on chronic abdominal pain in the setting of a recent 
traumatic fall resulting in possible rib fracture. CT abd/pelvis 
showed no PVT and infectious work up was negative, including a 
diagnostic paracentesis that showed no SBP.  The etiology 
remained unclear, possible due to baseline distention and 
umbilical hernias. Her morphine regimen was increased in 
frequency and her pain slowly improved. She tolerate tube feeds 
throughout this time. She was discharged on her home morphine 
regimen. 

# Decompensated HCV/EtOH Cirrhosis
She has a history of HCV/EtOH cirrhosis c/b ascites requiring 
weekly LVP (did not tolerate diuretics), esophageal/rectal 
varies and HE. Previously deemed to not be a transplant 
candidate. On admission, found to have MELD-Na 14, Child's Class 
B. Diagnostic paracentesis negative for SBP. Given last EGD on 
___ showed grade II varices in distal esophagus, she was trialed 
on nadolol 20mg QD beginning ___, but d/ced in setting of 
worsening Cr and Na. She continued to receive weekly LVP, last 
on ___ ___s lactulose and rifaxamin. She will need q6 
month HCC screening. 

#Adrenal insufficiency 
Given persistent hyperkalemia, morning cortisol was checked and 
found to be ~0.5 x2. Cosyntropin stimulation test then showed an 
inappropriate response concerning for adrenal insufficiency. 
Endocrine was consulted, recommended sending 21-hydroxylase Ab,  
pending at time of discharge, and holding off on imaging. She 
was discharged on hydrocortisone 10 mg am and 5 mg at 3 pm with 
plan to follow up in the ___ for further 
management, including possible repetition of the cosyntropin 
stimulation test and with aldosterone. 

# Odynophagia
Patient presented with white plaques on tongue and pain with 
swallowing, concern for ___ esophagitis. The symptoms also 
corresponded to two Dobhoff placements, so mechanical trauma to 
esophagus was also considered. She had only mild improvement 
with Nystatin/Fluconazole x 14 days. GI was consulted and 
recommended starting carafate and PPI for possible variceal 
irritation by ___. Overall her symptoms improved/remained 
stable. She should follow up with her PCP and GI as an 
outpatient to consider repeat EGD. 

# HCV, Genotype 1a
HCV VL undetectable earlier in ___. She was previously started 
on a 24 week course of sofosbuvir-velpatasvir (Epclusa) that was 
to end in late ___, but the patient had missed 
significant portion of the doses during serial admissions. She 
was asked to bring in the Epclusa but she had recently ran out. 
She will need to continue Epclusa as an outpatient, like for an 
extended period. She planned to refill her outpatient script 
upon discharge. 

# Normocytic anemia
# BRBPR
Patient has a history of chronic anemia in setting of cirrhosis, 
compounded by occasional blood loss from rectal varices. She had 
received 4 units of pRBCs in ___ prior to admission.  On ___, 
the patient developed blood-streaked stool and Hb dropped to 
6.8. She had no UGI symptoms or vital sign changes. She was 
transfused 1 unit on ___ and her Hgb remained stable around 
___. She will need a repeat CBC as an outpatient.  

#Malnutrition 
Noted to have very poor oral intake associated with significant 
weight loss in last month. ___ was placed this admission and 
tube feeds were started per nutrition recs. She should continue 
on tube feeds and tolerated her goal rate. Discharged with plan 
to continue them at home. 

#Disposition
Physical therapy evaluated the patient and recommended rehab. 
The patient refused and wished to be discharged home. Risks were 
reviewed, including concern for falls and serious harm. She 
understood the risks and still wished to go home. She was 
ultimately discharged home with home services with plan for 
close follow up.

provide extra nutrition. It could also be caused by a fungus 
called ___, and we started an anti-fungal medication to 
treat this. If this pain does not resolve, you may need an 
endoscopy to take a look at the esophagus.

We discussed your prognosis; unfortunately, with your liver 
disease, we can treat the symptoms but not the primary cause. As 
some point you will get an infection or bleed which we cannot 
treat. We don't think this will be tomorrow or next week, but it 
could be in a year or less. The palliative care team helped and 
will continue to help you make the best choices and support you 
in this difficult time.

You will need a repeat paracentesis on ___. Additionally, 
please start taking the new medications as described below. 

It was a privilege to care for you in the hospital, and we wish 
you all the best.

Sincerely,

Ms. ___ is a ___ y/o woman with decompensated HCV/EtOH 
cirrhosis, admitted for spontaneous vs. secondary peritonitis,

ACUTE ISSUES:
=============
#GI bleed
Patient noted to have had a large bloody bowel movement on 
___. In discussion with the patient and her HCP, 
investigation/treatment of this would require intubation which 
was not w/in the patient's GOC. With this in mind, in addition 
to her multiple medical issues discussed below and her numerous 
admissions in the past year, the patient and HCP decided that 
continuing aggressive treatment was only prolonging of the 
inevitable and the patient was transitioned to CMO. 

#Acute Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure
On ___, patient was found struggling to breath. O2 sat was 82% 
on 2L and tachypneic in ___. SBP started to rise peaking up to 
220s and HR was in the 140s. She was given lasix 80mg, and 
placed on non-rebreather mask following which O2 sat increased 
to mid-90s. However, she continued to be tachypneic in ___ with 
SBP>200. Stat CXR and clinical assessment suggested flash 
pulmonary edema vs. ARDS ___ to infection which was c/b 
decompensated cirrhosis. She is DNI/DNR though respiratory code 
was called and she was placed on BiPAP. She was transferred to 
ICU for BiPAP management, nitro drip for HTN management, and 
volume control. She was transitioned to CMO when transferred 
back to the floor when her family, the patient, and HCP decided 
that her GOC did not include continued respiratory support. It 
was felt that she would not recover from her sepsis, GI 
bleeding, and pulmonary edema.

# HYPOTENSION, likely due:  
# SEPSIS:  
# ADRENAL INSUFFICIENCY:
