bandemia, GPC bacteremia, and peritonitis. CXR on admission with 
infiltrate concerning for possible HAP. Diagnostic para was 
consistent with SBP. She was started with 
vanc/cefepime/metronidazole ___ transition). Additionally, 
patient has known adrenal insufficiency and she was started on 
stress dose steroids hydrocortisone 50mg Q8hrs which was 
discontinued on transition to CMO.

# GPC BLOODSTREAM INFECTION:  
Patient with GPCs in cluster and pairs. Regarding sources, there 
was concern for enterococcal source from GI. Additionally 
patient with risks for MRSA including many recent 
hospitalizations. She was continued on Vancomycin, and ID was 
consulted. However, she was transferred to ICU before speciation 
was determined. When transferred back to the floor, ID was 
consulted and felt that this organism was a contaminant. 

#Severe Ascites
#HCV/EtOH Cirrhosis: 
Child's Class B on admission. Previously decompensated by 
ascites (did not tolerate diuretics), esophageal varices, and 
HE. Diagnostic para in ED positive for SBP, though she had had 
multiple recent paras that were negative for SBP. 

# PERITONITIS - SPONTANEOUS vs. SECONDARY:  
Concomitant GPC bacteremia and significant abdominal pain raised 
some concern for secondary peritonitis. However, ___ 
criteria suggested otherwise (ascitic protein<1.0, glucose>50; 
LDH not checked). Studies concerning for SBP however. Given 
above discussion of other potential sources, she was started on 
Cefepime.

worsening liver function in setting of sepsis.

evidence on exam but has known esophageal and rectal varices.

Active issues: 
___: Patient noted to have elevation of his Cr to 2.6 on ___ 
which peaked at 2.8 on ___. Baseline Cr is 0.6-0.7. This is of 
unclear etiology. Patient had no episodes of hypotension, urine 
microscopy was unremarkable (few granular casts, no other 
findings) and renal U/S was unrevealing (no evidence for 
thrombus/emboli).  Pt was clinically euvolemic and no 
improvement with IVF. Possibly related to contrast though timing 
not perfect. At time of discharge, Cr was downtrending to 2.4.

# Lung abscess: History of recent PE on coumadin with symptoms 
and imaging consistent with likely lung abscess. He had a CT 
scan that showed a right lung abscess with air fluid level. He 
was placed on vanco and zosyn and ID was consulted. They 
recommended ___ weeks of IV antibiotics. CT surgery was also 
consulted who ultimately felt that surgery was not appropriate 
in the acute setting. It appears that the abscess is draining 
through his airway at this time. Thoracics will see the patient 
as an outpt to evaluate for possible surgical options after 
___ of antibiotics. Patient should obtain repeat CT Chest 
scan prior to stopping antibiotics. In the setting of his ___ 
(see above), pt's Zosyn dose was reduced to 2.25g q8 hrs from 
4.5g q8hrs and his Vancomycin was reduced to 1000mg q48 hours 
from 1250mg IVq8hrs. As his kidney function improves, his 
antibiotic dosing will need adjustments. 

# Hemoptysis: Likely ___ PE and lung abscess complicated by 
supratherapeutic INR which was improving by time of admission to 
the MICU with FFP and vitamin K. He never had any evidence of 
active bleeding and was felt to be stable for the floor.

# Septic pulmonary emboli: Right-sided PEs noted on imaging and 
patient being treated with coumadin on admission. Patient taking 
Keflex since the diagnosis of PE was made. The OSH felt the PE 
could be septic emboli so he was being treated with Keflex 
prophylactically. Given the above hemoptysis his anticoagulation 
was held during his MICU course. In further review of OSH 
records (including LENIs which showed no DVTs) and conversation 
with ID and ICU team, it was felt that these all represent 
septic emboli and not thrombotic disease. As a result, pt was 
kept off anticoagulation and discharged without warfarin or 
alternative blood thinner.  

# Endocarditis: Recent history of TV endocarditis that was 
treated with 6 weeks of IV nafcillin. Patient did not have any 
signs on admission, but blood cultures were drawn and came back 
negative. He had a cardiac echo that showed possibly a small 
vegetation on his TV; however, TEE revealed no vegetations and 
he was felt to have cleared any evidence of active endocarditis. 


Chronic issues: 
# Anemia: Unclear if chronic or acute. Given the illness over 
the last several months, likely chronic related to inflammation. 
However, given the hemoptysis could also be related to blood 
loss.  Iron studies were checked and were not abnormal. Over the 
course of his hospitalization his blood counts remained stable. 
He was started back on his home iron supplement on discharge.

# IVDA: Complicated social situation with long hx of drug abuse 
and recent withdrawal from stopping methadone. Patient's mother 
involved and concerned about addiction problems.  He was seen by 
social work, but the patient declined to speak with them. 
Attempts were made to limit narcotics and benzos after his 
mother reported that she felt that he was abusing them more than 
he should on prior admissions. He was continued on his home 
oxycodone and xanax with good effect. He did not ask for 
additional medications during the course of his hospitalization. 


# Depression: He was continued on his home citalopram, 
alprazolam and mirtazapine.
